review:
[h1]F1 2019 vs F1 2020[/h1]
[b]Is 2020 better looking?[/b]
[i]- Looks about the same.[/i]
[b]Is 2020 Gameplay better?[/b]
[i]- Yes[/i]
[b]Is 2020 better overall?[/b]
[i]- yes[/i]
[b]Is 2020 worth the upgrade?[/b]
[i]- Yes[/i]
[b]So does that mean 2020 is now the best F1 game?[/b]
[i]- Yupp[/i]


[h1]F1 2019 Review[/h1]
[quote][h1]F1 game for the masses[/h1]
[b]DLC‚Äôs[/b] let‚Äôs just get that out of the way, just don‚Äôt bother getting any of them, you not missing anything nor does if effect your gameplay. Just leave it‚Ä¶

[b]Difficulty,[/b] well it‚Äôs a game for the masses, you can make it really hard or you can make it really easy and arcade like. Does not feel like it compromises in whatever you prefer. If you like to game on a controller or steering wheel, both work perfectly fine and can be adjusted to your gameplay style.

[b]Graphics,[/b] I‚Äôm running everything on ultra but never had an ‚Äúoh wow‚Äù moment. Have some other Codemasters games also from 2019 where I actually had those moments.

[b]Gameplay,[/b] rock solid! You do need to think about your components in your car, as in you don‚Äôt want to wear them to fast or they do break and you will get a DNF. Planning ahead does feel rewarding, to upgrading to driving more carefully to saving fuel or spare the few tires you got, or just simple heat management. It‚Äôs all there with develop new parts to installing them or just speeding up your pit times. That said I never felt overwhelmed by it, all been easy to understand also there are ton of tutorials in the game with solid voice overs and text.

[b]Previous F1 games,[/b] well I have not played one for more than a decade sooo‚Ä¶ That said I‚Äôve played tons racing games since Stunts that you played on DOS back in the early 90‚Äôs, just not the F1 series.

https://steamcommunity.com/id/Scorpidoo/recommended/928600/

title: F1 2020
review: F1 2020 is a great game, i recommend it for anyone who likes or watches f1 this game features a driving career were you become a driver and do f1 races and race all the other guys etc. Now the reason you want to get this game is the new feature to this years game the MY Team mode this is were you become a owner AND a driver of a team that you create you can choose your engine supplier get F1 and F2 drives for your team new department upgrades like upgrading the time or how many upgrades you can buy at a time. This game also features driver transfers drivers retiring drives from f2 becoming f1 drivers Sponsors and for your team (and sponsor goals for extra cash.). There is also a online racing mechanic were you can race other drivers in ranked or unranked matches in ranked you basically vs people similar to your rank (you start from unranked and get to build rank like bronze silver gold diamond etc). Overall this is a great game and i recommend it for anybody that likes racing or is interested in buying it i give it a 10/10.

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 Series by Codemasters is nothing short of amazing. Either for virtual racing enthusiasts and newcomers to racing in general.

The game has features to enhance newcomers experiences with high levels of driving assists. The great part about this is being welcome to a greater portion of potential consumers outside the racing niche.

The game also has zero assists options for veterans. The player can remove assists such as traction control and ABS for a more genuine F1 and F2 experience.

This time, F1 2020 has vastly improved the formula of CM F1 titles, with features additions and graphics enhancements also for handling. F1 2020 has a much better tire model than the previous F1 2019 had. We now have the awesome My Team mode, where you create the 11th team on the grid, race and grind for car improvements during a dynamic career mode we already had previously.

Circuits selection is based on the first 2020 official calendar, so you can count on two brand new and laser scanned tracks as Zandvoort and Hanoi GP. 

Suzuka has taken some love from the devs and now counts with a smoother asphalt after the last chicane that previously had an infamous bump.

Cons lies on older circuits that were made years ago and saddly doesn't stand the test of time, specially with now laser scanned circuits. These circuits are in the form of SPA, Hungaroring and Monaco. I believe they are the only ones left for a major revamp as they feature not realistic cambering, hard tarmac elevation changes that are not there in real life and wonky curbs.

SPA GP circuit is in dire need of a total revamp and possibly from a proper laser scan, as the original we have wasn't made with such technology. Curbs are in totally wrong shape, making it sometimes dangerously high for the car as in the amazing turn 12. Saddly, we have to wait to see a proper Spa-Francorchamps circuit.

The game physics is not on the level of iRacing, Assetto Corsa, rFactor 2 and other sims, but surely does the complete experience of a Formula 1 weekend with full rules and dynamic weather. Graphics are sensational and optimization is high end.

As an old Grand Prix 3 fan...This is the best Formula 1 game made to date. Codemasters still improves on every single title since F1 2016, sometimes strongly, sometimes not that much.

Highly recommend. Infinite amount of entertainment.

title: F1 2020
review:
Amazing game, I'll go over online first.

Online -

Not much changes in terms of development and additions, except for a few new liveries for the custom car. But also the addition of lapped cars being ghosted, which is great, especially in ranked when people get salty and try to take out the leader. Good stuff on that. Other than that nothing much has changed. Not sure what else they can change but Online is pretty good for right now. Setups are also massively important this year more than any other, and this will be very evident in online, you'll find yourself possibly over a second off, if your using a balanced setup. It's really recommended that you either download or create your custom setup, or else you might find yourself at the back and in danger of being taken out at turn 1.

Single Player - 

My Team, my goodness me. I don't believe anyone ever expected this, but it's incredible, create your own team, appoint your own teamate from F2 Drivers to current F1 Drivers, multiple departments where you can decrease or increase morale. There are plenty of sponsors that are your main source of income, they are also placed onto your car, race suit and helmet. A bit more of customization is a good sight in this game. F1 drivers can now retire as well. The only negative from this game is the slight decrease of AI Aggressiveness, there is no denying there speed, but there wheel to wheel racing has gone down a bit, sometimes they completely turn into you, or just brake and completely back out of a fight, which is pretty inconsistent. The second bad thing are the starts, probably the worst it's been since 2015 in terms of starts, it's nearly impossible to get a good start every time against the AI. It's possible, but unlikely.

Overall, amazing game, small negatives and small bugs, but that's normal. Good job Codemasters.

review: I am a returning player of the franchise, having last played the 2010, '11 and '12 F1 games. Man am I impressed by the improvements! The cars respond so precisely to the Dualshock4 controller throttle input, it made me enjoy lap after lap after lap right from the very first time I got into the car seat. The audio design of the F1 cars are extremely good too! I watched the real F1 race highlights this season and the car audio was literally the same as in the game. Amazing job overall. Career mode is very very immersive and allows one to engage with it as much as they want, with the option to simulate sessions if you find them cumbersome to do. I loved doing all the sessions all the time because of how well the car reacts to my inputs.

title: F1 2020
review:
Controller user here.
Miles better than its predecessor F1 2019. No more floaty cars that don't brake, now the cars are planted and actually do what you tell them to.

My Team provides a fresh outlook at career mode which was becoming a bit stagnant. There aren't that many liveries to choose from at the moment, though that should change in time. However, if you are looking for a pure F1 manager experience with no driving, this is NOT the game for you. Get Motorsport Manager instead.

There's only 6 championships to choose from in Championship mode however. And classic cars seem to have been ported straight from 2019, with little effort made to update their handling.

Otherwise, this game is enjoyable and a must have for F1 enthusiasts.

title: F1 2020
review:
MyCareer is such a fun addition to the game. The same career mode year after year was getting rather repetitive despite the improvements to it, and being able to drive your own car for your own team is always a cool and enjoyable concept.

The customization is pretty nice, cars feel really good to drive and the A.I can provide a decent challenge to average players, though the top drivers still seem to find it a bit too easy even on 110 difficulty.

As usual there are some balancing issues with how quickly you can improve in career, A.I being too quick or too slow on certain parts of certain tracks and I can't speak for online, but otherwise it's one of the best, if not THE best F1 game Codemasters has released to date, in terms of single player content.

title: F1 2020
review:
[h1] More of the same, Deluxe edition lacking [/h1]
I've marked this as Not Recommended but to be honest it's a very slim margin and if there was a middle of the road 5/10 option, this would be it.

TLDR version: If you liked 2019 you'll like this as it's more of the same, but to it's detriment. Too much recycled content, My Team frustrations with liveries/colours. Second driver growth is painfully slow. Schumacher Edition isn't worth it. 2019 had Senna-Prost content with race events based around points in their career. in 2020 the Schumi edition is just a bunch of cosmetics.

Full Review:
From 2019, the addition of My Team is nice, it's where most of my hours have been put in. Also the handling feels different in a good way.
Sadly though that's all I can kinda highlight as new or different in this over the 2019 version.

As is kinda (sadly) expected from annual titles, there is a lot.. a LOT.. of recycled content from last year or two of F1 games.
-Practice tasks are exactly the same (Track acclim, tyre management, race strat etc.) Which can all be completed in less than one practice session, with no real incentive to do Practice 2 & 3 as once they're done, they're done.
-Paddock interview questions and answers are completely identical to last year, not having any new questions at all, or changing the format feels really lazy.
-Classic content is EXACTLY the same as last year, the same classic championship winning cars like Alonso's Renault, the Brawn GP car etc that were in F1 2019.
-The ERS management on the HUD is the same even though the use of it has been changed, so you have a mostly pointless HUD option to change ers mode but only between Medium/Overtake/None when you already have a toggle button.

There are also a few quality of life things that I feel were missed opportunities and frustrating when playing the game.
-My Team mode resource point generation feels really slow the further along the R&D tree you go.
-Acclaim point growth hits a wall and really starts to become a slow grind.
-In My Team, if you want to try and pick a second driver from the lower ranks  and stick with them, rather than changing drivers with higher skill and contracts, their growth is almost painfully slow, with facility boosts only having a limited effect and activities only giving +2 to a single stat, it really frustrating.
-The custom liveries are such a missed opportunity, only giving you the option to recolour a few templates rather than a full fledged editor like in the Forza or NFS series. Also the colour picker is frustrating as you can't save previously used colours.
-Overtake being an on/off button press rather than a press and hold like in the current F1 cars.

Schumacher Edition
It's really not worth it.
While 2019's Senna/Prost edition gave us a few races and track events based around points in their career at least, this year the Schumacher Edition is just a bunch of cosmetics and nothing else.

Overall
Have I and will I continue to sink hours into this game? Yes
Because if you enjoyed 2019, you'll enjoy 2020, because it's more of the same.
But a bit TOO MUCH of the same.
They could've really gone with something fresher for a new decade of f1 games but there's so much copy-paste from 2019s game it's a real let down.

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 2020 is easily the best of Codemaster's attempts at making a solid F1 game. 

Pros:
- Great physics. Even though it's not a pure simulation, driving in F1 2020 feels engaging and complex. 
- Awesome AI. The AI produces some great battles and makes for a very solid opponent whatever mode you're playing. 
- My Team mode and driver movements. Adds a cool layer of management to all the racing even though it's not all that feature-rich. 

Cons:
- There still are bugs despite Codemasters using a very old engine. In one case, the game crashed at the final lap of a 50% race. 
- There are micro-transactions. Cosmetics only but still. 
- Locking the Schumacher content behind a DLC is, well, not great.

title: F1 2020
review:
[b]DON'T BUY THE GAME JUST FOR MULTIPLAYER.[/b] 

Multiplayer hasn't changed since the last game and if anything it got worse. The day Codesmasters actually makes a good F1 game is when Multiplayer is actually enjoyable and not filled with brain dead, lead-footed, low IQ drivers. The game needs a reporting system and on top of that have a system in place like Overwatch in CSGO where multiple experienced players review a set of incidents in a race and all vote on whether a ban should be given to said player.

I've heard My Team is good. I don't really have any plans on playing it. I haven't touched Career mode and I'm sure that hasn't changed as well.

Verdict: Don't buy the game strictly for the multiplayer. If you want to get it just for My Team/Career mode go for it but It will probably get old after a while.

The vibrations make the speed feel... Fast. I have already put a bunch of hours in this and it just came out. F12020 is the only sports game that actually improved this year.

title: F1 2020
review:
The question most people have when a new game in a yearly series releases is, Is this worth it for the ¬£45/¬£50 price point... In this case, I believe it is. Fair enough, i missed out on F1 2019 because I didn't see it adding a lot to the previous iteration of the franchise. This game however does a lot to add to a formula (no pun intended) that was getting stale.

But why...
- My Team, the new addition to the game, adds a new layer of gameplay that truly makes you care about your team and its success. After starting out with the mode and having a bit of fun, bringing the lord and saviour Raghunathan in as a 2nd driver and witnessing him come dead last every race whilst I was slowly getting closer to the points as the season progressed... I got more irritated as the season progressed and changed him out. The personalisation is nice and keeps you caring about every action. However, this isn't without complaint because all that has really been added is a bit of behind the scenes management and being able to drive your own personalised car... races are the same, as are interviews post-race.

A few graphics have been added for pit stops which is a nice touch, but nothing major for the races and career modes. AI have been updated though and do make more punchy moves which throw you off your usual lines to defend against them. Some tracks, like the new Zandvoort Circuit, still have easy ways to keep the AI behind most of the time unless you have horrific driving ability or tyre wear and therefore you can get points with the rest of the field in a processional line behind you. For the most part though, it's a nice new challenge and the AI are more unpredictable in their moves.

Online is as it always has been... mainly chaos with a few decent races in there. I've ended up getting bronze tier ranking from placements simply because of first corner punts from behind and the side ruining a whole race as people forget the brake pedal exists. Fair enough, I'm not the greatest of drivers but try to keep out of conflict as much as possible. Some races have been quite pleasant, first lap wing changes creating some good battles with other drivers who found themselves in a similar situation. It just needs a function like Forza where it can predict collisions from high speeds card launching into slow corners for the experience to be tolerable.

Wheel support is, as usual, very good... Force Feedback is nice in telling you about understeer and oversteer, allowing you to react in time along with the pitch perfect engine noises to give you similar indications. The mobile phone ring of the Ferrari engine downshifts is a personal favourite to hear as I pass them, or they pass me.

There are still some updates needed though... liveries still haven't been updated to the #WeRaceAsOne versions and Ferrari still have the most powerful engine and their performance hasn't been decreased as it should have been after the first performance patch. 

All we need is a realistic setting where Mercedes winning qualifying by a second causes the commentators jto say "Why did they win today?" "Because they're Mercedes... They're just miles better." (and I say that from a McLaren fans perspective). 

So overall... is it good. Yes, this franchise has been on the up since 2016/ 2017... This is yet another improvement but if you're hesitant... just get it on sale, it's inevitable it will be half price within 6 months.

title: F1 2020
review:
A great F1 game. Some welcome improvements to car handling and ERS management over last year's game, following input from real F1 drivers who raced in the Formula 1 virtual championship during plague lockdown. Minor improvements to graphics, which in 2019 was already a massive step up. My Team career is a great new addition, and I'm really enjoying playing as the owner, manager, and star driver of the 11th team on the grid.

If you're a hardcore sim racer, you might dismiss this game as not being "realistic" (translation: difficult) enough. But for me, it's about as much of a simulation as I need it to be. For inexperienced players, there are plenty of driver aids to help ease the learning curve. There's also a new casual mode, which can help even complete newcomers enjoy the satisfaction of winning races.

In terms of content, the full original 22-race 2020 F1 calendar is represented. Sadly, none of the replacement tracks for this year's actual season will make it to the game, but let's hold thumbs for a Covid Edition DLC in 2021. There are also classic cars, including Michael Schumacher's title-winning cars in the Schumacher Edition DLC. In addition, there's a full 2019 F2 season (with 2020 tracks), with the 2020 season to be added at some point.

A more divisive new addition is a "battle pass" season type of system, where you gain XP that unlocks cosmetic items and Pitcoins. You can either purchase Pitcoins for real money. More interesting, though, are the daily, weekly, and premium challenges, which also nets more XP.

I would definitely recommend this game for F1 fans, and anyone curious about driving the world's fastest race cars virtually. If you don't care about having the most current drivers and tracks, you can probably save a few bucks and buy F1 2019 on sale instead. But depending on the price in your region, the improvements and new additions in F1 2020 are well worth the money at full price, provided you buy it shortly after release, and play it until F1 2021 is released. Otherwise, get it on the Steam Holiday Sale at the end of the year for a nice discount.

title: F1 2020
review:
Through no real fault of Codemasters' own, the authenticity that's been a hallmark of its F1 series isn't quite there this year. How could it be when the season it's replicating remains a moving target? Having started some four months later than planned, we're still not entirely sure what the rest of the F1 2020 calendar is going to bring, with visits to circuits like Portimao, Imola and Mugello on the cards - none of which will make it into this year's game, while Zandvoort and Hanoi, two new races we'll never get to see this year, find a place in the game's circuit roster. Even the liveries have changed fast in the build-up to yesterday's season opener - the now Rokit-less Williams is part of a day one patch, and you'll likely have to wait a little while after launch until you're able to race Mercedes' freshly black and jaw-droppingly beautiful new look.
Well, that was my own tale, and F1 2020 provided me with the systems to be able to play it out. You pick out your team colours and livery in an editor that, for all its limitations, provides some fairly convincing results. You select sponsors - they're made-up brands and companies, which actually seems fairly authentic to the F1 underworld of financiers and mythical energy drink slurping enigmas - and manage contracts and facilities alongside the R&D upgrade tree, juggling resources amongst the lot. I'm a big fan of how 10-race seasons are now an option, making that progress all the more instant and just as gratifying - because when it comes together, and you're working alongside the F2 hotshot you hired to make a crash and grab on the last few points-paying positions, F1 2020's new team management mode feels legit.

It's helped along by handling that keeps making forward strides. There's a new, more accessible pad setting, complemented elsewhere by tweaked wheel settings that keep you that little bit busier when hustling around a track. Most importantly, whichever way you're playing, everything feels whippet quick and responsive. It's all a bit overstated, as is the AI, which is equal parts courteous and aggressive with not much subtlety in between, but that's just fine. This isn't iRacing or rFactor 2, yet in its own way F1 2020 is faithful to the real thing. Besides, I don't think you'll be playing either of those big sims on a sofa with a friend in splitscreen, as you can now finally do in an F1 game once again.

title: F1 2020
review:
As mentioned before, I have to change my review.

Many of the most frustrating Bugs are fixed.
It is still not what I would consider a good Game, due to the MTX involved but at least you can actual have fun with it.

The driving physics are better then in the previous installments. The car has actual weight that you feel through the corners. Acceleration and deceleration destabilize your car as it should.

Unfortunately that is the only improvement you can point your finger at in comparison to F1 2019

The KI feels still stupid. Getting themselves in positions where they will never get an advantage besides getting in your way. Qualifying times seem to be dependent on your first run.

Another thing which is very irritating is that you can deactivate Auto Save, but then you don't have any means to save.
There is only a "mid race save" feature but that's the only one in the entire game. If you want to save between P1 and P2 you are out of luck.

In regards to dealing with Codemaster themselves, just don't.
You still need to fill out a form just to tell them about bugs. To get heard you have to do Q&A for them in the first place. Best case is you decompile the game, fix the bugs yourself and only then tell them about it.

This game is still not worth the money they want, but at least its worth being called a game. Wait for a 50% deal and play the shit out of F1 2019. You are not missing out.
As always, I will change my review as things change, but for now that's the status.

title: F1 2020
review:
It's like F1 2019 but updated, kinda like FIFA games. The new major addition is "My Team" career, in which you manage your own team. It is really fun. 
Now to the bad things:
-the AI remained extremely inconsistent across tracks (on the same difficulty setting, i come 15th in one race and then easily win another one)
-there are some translation issues (in polish)
-the AI sometimes fails to notice you being on the inside and just turns into you
-the microtransaction system is something that doesn't really fit the game
-the goddamn Podium Pass, which would be fine if it was for free, sadly it isn't
And the good things are:
-updated physics
-My Team mode
-simplified ERS management (instead of switching between modes manually, you just have an Overtake button)
Other than that it is just F1 2019 but updated. If you enjoyed 2019, you will surely enjoy this one.

title: F1 2020
review:
So I bought this game on impulse after wanting to play a more realistic racing game.  I usually play arcade racers, and after a dozen hours playing, here's my review:

The game has a lot of depth and accessibility options, allowing you to tune the game to your liking. Not all of it is straightforward though, and some options are pretty hidden, so I suggest you take your time browsing through all the menus because the game's tutorial will not hold your hand.
If you ever played Dirt 4, F1 2020 has the same My Team mode as that game, and it adds a lot of replayability and much needed variety to a F1 game. The flashback function so present in every Codemasters racer is also in this game, but this time without any downsides to its use, so it's entirely up to you to limit yourself or abuse the flashbacks as much as you want.

The biggest problem I've found with the game so far, is actually on the gameplay side of things. The game sits on the fence between simulation and fun, which is not a bad thing, but that means it also lacks some things you'd expect from this type of game.
There's no random engine failures for the player. The AI's cars might randomly fail through the race, but yours won't, ever. The damage model on this game is bordering on nonexistent, which I assume is because the sponsoring brands don't want their precious stickers being damaged by modern mesh deformation technology, so while the cars in real life are fragile and soft, the cars in this game are coated in trademarkium and are by all means, unbreakable.
The AI also seems to have a larger range of turning than the player does, which means they'll often take corners at much higher speeds than you will, which I assume is to compensate for their constant premature braking before curves. Seriously, over half of your overtakes will be because the AI decided to brake much earlier on simpler curves, meanwhile tracks like Monaco, they will fly through curves at double your speed.

Races can be huge too, and some races even on 50% lenght, can have as much as 35 laps. You can pick between having 5 laps/25%/50%/100% races lenght, but honestly going above 25% is something you should avoid unless you're doing one off races. The game for whatever stupid reason will sometimes randomly black screen after a race, and if that happens, the entire race progress has been lost. 
That means if you just spent the last 60/90m doing a 50%/100% race on carreer mode and the game suddenly decides to black screen, not only your entire progress is lost which means you gotta redo the entire race, but the game DOES NOT ALLOW YOU to change race lenght on race day, which means you gotta either retire from the race or do the entire thing again and hope this time the game goes through.
Overtaking backmarkers is also as frustrating as it is in real life, which makes you wonder why the hell FiA still allows B-Teams to compete in the same race as A-Teams, specially when teams like Alfa Romeo are just Ferrari's spare parts.

There is also a huge discrepancy between race difficulty and practice difficulty. Even on the lowest possible difficulty settings, practice mode will still often have simply unreachable goals. And failing practice goals means you get less points to upgrade your car with. Thankfully the game allows you to simulate practice mode so you can skip it entirely and get points out of it. The game also lets you simulate races if you ever wanna skip a track you dislike or a rainy track.

Rain in this game might aswell be hot butter, it makes your car lose all grip and just slide along every single curve. I did two rainy races so far, and on both times half the AI cars crashed out of the race on the first 30s.

Finally, the game also has some battle pass crap and a cash shop, which lets you buy random gloves, outfits, car decals, helmets and podium poses to customize your character and team with. Character customization is the bare minimum, as you just get to pick between one of many male presets and a few reptilian "females". 
You can customize your character any time you want, including changing his/xir presets and name, but any change in clothing aside from helmet will not be reflected on the carreer mode, so you're basically spending money on content you can only use on half of the game.

In the end, I really enjoy this game for what it is, but it's clear it could be so much more. I never played previous F1 games or racing simulations in general but I truly like this game, as it leans more towards the 'game' side of things.

title: F1 2020
review:
Best F1 game out there, thought it was just a reboot with a few extra steps but the new my team and rewards system makes the game so much more rewarding since there's more than just a prefix that says "champion" on the line but the fundamental economics and developments that shape the future and performance your F1 team. To sum up the game in ratings;
Replayability 10/10
Graphics 8.5/10 (subtle but not largely noticeable changes from F12019)
Gameplay 10/10
Force Feedback 8/10 (Still having oversteer issues with the G29)
Is it worth the 60$ pricetag? If you're into F1, team management, and competitive offline and online racing, this game is definitely  for you, it's built to be difficult and/or easy. It's made to bring joy to it's users but is stressful when you don't get the results you wanted. It's a racing sim that's built for everybody. Enjoyed it the most with a wheel.

title: F1 2020
review: The game can be extremely fickle when it comes to stability. You won't get help from Steam or the developer when attempting to fix these issues but the community will try to help with valuable suggestions. One suggestion I did not hear and that helped the game to run smoothly for me was to not use a bluetooth control. As long as I plug the controller into the PC the game doesn't crash and will run smoothly... for the most part with just a few screen dumps hear and there with frame rate drop. Otherwise this is a great racing sim.

title: F1 2020
review:
Graphics: great
Optimzed well for PC: Slightly overclocked 1080 FE (+150 clock speed) on a 3700X and I get 90-100 FPS on 1440p
My Team: Really fun if you play solo a lot and have no plans to play online.  A great addition I hope is here to stay.

However, to really, really enjoy this game, you must join a simracing league IMO.  I've been playing F1 games since 2016 and have never really put more than 20 hours into these games.  Once I joined a sim racing league, my time skyrocketed, as you'll find yourself working on your racecraft, practicing the same track over and over, all to just potentially bin it in turn 3 on an online race that isn't full of torpedo users.  You'll also start meeting people and having conversations about F1, MotoGP, and other motorsports. 

In other words, it is the gateway to the premium racing experience that a ranked/unranked lobby could almost never produce.

Overall: A great game with some bugs that have lasted over the years for some reason.  Also, with the coronavirus, a lot of F1 drivers are playing the game, and even F1 had an e-sports championship, but this game is not very commentator friendly.

review: Gentlemen a short view back to the past Thirty years ago, Niki Lauda told us: "Take a trained monkey place him into the cockpit and he is able to drive the car" Thirty years later Sebastian told us: "I had to start my car like a computer It's very complicated" And Nico Rosbeg said, err, he pressed during the race I don't remember what race the wrong buttonon the wheel Question for you to both Is formula 1 driving today too complicated with 20 and more buttons on the wheel are you too much under effort under pressure? What are your wishes for the future concerning technical program, errrm, during the race? Less buttons more? Or less and more comunication with your engineers?

title: F1 2020

title: F1 2020
review:
Best game Codemasters has made to date. My team is fun, handling model is much better. The sounds are actually nearly bang on.

However the crashes on pc were a disaster but i have now fixed these. The same in f12019 ...

Make sure you install window updates, update your graphics and run in DX11 if you ever have issues. Even though i run a nvidia rtx 2080 i crashed a lot. But changing my graphics to medium fixed this,

I'd recommend this game 100%

title: F1 2020

The game is optimized incredibly well it pumps out 1440p 144hz as well as 4k 60 with absolute ease, just beautiful. Highly recommend.

title: F1 2020
review:
AI is really fun to race and actually fights back this time. Haven't met a single game breaking bug at the time I made this review (48hrs). Codemasters actually released polished F1 game this time :)

My experience from different controllers:
Steering wheel = Best choice for serious racing. Logitech and Thrustmaster wheels work really well from my experience. Both are easy to setup.
Controller = Feels good but not as accurate, you might need some assists that ultimately slow you down in lap times.
Keyboard = No go zone in any case.

title: F1 2020
review: I'm a hardcore F1 fan so I won't really skip an F1 title. Graphically the game is similar to 2019 but they've really pushed the physics. The handling is more believable and racing is fun. The AI is pretty smart and aggressive too defending the inside lines and following your tail for the slipstream. They've added various podium celebrations and that's a win! I haven't started the famous my team mode yet partly because I'm waiting for the performance update. That said the game indeed does have loads of bugs. Hopefully it gets addressed soon. Will update my review once I start the My Team mode.

title: F1 2020
review: The create a team is a lot of fun, and the sliding AI difficulty scale makes it so you can be as competitive as you want to be right from the start. Online is pretty good and pretty fun. I've really enjoyed it so far.

title: F1 2020
review:
In my opinion, I would say that this is definitely the best game out there for formula one simulation and no other game comes close but it is not without its faults.

Starting off with singleplayer, the most frustrating thing is trying top nail the difficulty and I feel like there needs to be some sort of benchmarking mode where you complete a few laps or a race and the game gives you a difficulty that you should use. The main problems that i am having with this is that the difficulty that I play at makes it way too difficult to complete practice programs successfully but I end up doing a lot better in qualifying. Furthermore, in the race, I end up doing a lot better than I should in the car that i am in. It just makes no sense at all and is not at all realistic. This overall leads to a very annoying experience. I love formula one as a sport but I feel that this game is too flawed for me to have any fun in.

Now onto the online mode. I personally only play ranked as it has the fewest dirty drivers however in every lobby I go into there are always drivers that either are not very good at the game or drivers that are just straight up dirty and try to ruin your race. This leads to a very annoying experience that is made very hard to enjoy. I am unsure of how this can be improved but something needs to be done. 

In conclusion, this game is very flawed and I find it very hard to enjoy. I would not recommend it for anyone wanting to play the game seriously at all. As far as new players go, codemasters have made it quite easy for you to pick up the game and play but the difficulty system will be vary annoying and it will be hard to find a difficulty that suits you at all. Would not recommend!

title: F1 2020
review:
I haven't even begun to try My Team or any F1 content, not even historical F1 cars. Half way through an F2 season I can recommend F1 2020 for sure. The sim is amazing in the dry and wet, it's a seamless experience and a well designed one, much improvement over F1 2017 which I played last. 

To pour some whine into it, the AI level seems very inconsistent between different circuits, practice programmes, qualifying and the races. I'm hoping this is either an issue more pronounced in F2 or something that will be patched soon. I can race decently within 75-90% AI but some of the practice programmes can be impossibly hard even with this moderate AI level, leading to some frustration.

Regarding the micro-transactions, I was also worried but I'm not bothered by it. Might be a matter of taste, but to this day I haven't unlocked anything in the podium pass VIP section that I would want on my car/character, so they are basically options for those want to have everything or with some particular items aligning with their taste. The best content seems to be free anyway.

title: F1 2020
review:
What can i say, the only proper F1 game. It has much more easier access for casual player now, so its not entirely simulation.

You can do a mod into the game, like changing the livery, helmet, sponsorship and such.

They upgraded career mode with a brand new "My Team". 

In a nutshell, you can make your own team into F1 Calendar. 

And no, its not like those 2K games bullshit that requires microtransaction to be success.

If you are following F1, not a bad game.

But if you are looking for proper simulation game, go for AC.

PS: Vietnam GP circuit is a turd

title: F1 2020
review:
This latest instalment from codemasters is certainly its best. My Team is is just what we needed to keep things fresh.
F1 2020 perfectly encapsulates the real life season into this easy to use game, great looking menus, reworked and better handling model and even better graphics make this game the best in the series.

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 2019: I'm the best F1 game.
F1 2020: Hold my overtake.

Edit: Black mercedes livery is finally here and looks awesome.

I'm having a great experience in multiplayer so far, even in ranked games. Racing on a controller is a lot better, it's a lot easier to handle the car when it starts to get unstable. Overtake button makes the ers a lot better, before you had like 5 options, now it's just a button!

As offline racing goes, only tested out the time trial which seems the same. Did not check the "My Team" and Career game modes yet.  

Visually it seems the same as before but some players might like the addition of dynamic resolution that makes your FPS more stable. Overall the game seems very optimised. 

Tip: For people struggling with FPS, try disabling the SSRT Shadows option.

title: F1 2020
review:
A buggy, broken nightmare.

While the game is much more polished in terms of its visuals compared to its predecessors, and the gameplay is much improved, you won't get to spend much time enjoying it.

Codemasters have the worst QA testing record of any series. Many of the bugs that have been present since 2012 are still there, but worse has arrived with the My Team mode. This is a great feature beset by bugs, crashes and glitches that have plagued and broken three save files.

After 71 hours I am now sending emails to Steam and Codemasters requesting a refund for an unplayable game - neither of them taking responsibility for it. Avoid until they fix, or steer clear all together - don't waste your money

title: F1 2020
review:
massive step up from last year's game, AI are a lot more competitive (though a lot more inaccurate because racing point slow and ferrari fast) and ERS has been massively improved with only 3 modes (medium, hotlap and overtake) which is a lot less complicated than the 6 modes of last year's game lol. i like the ability to see the 4 racers you are sandwiched in between instead of 2 on last year's game, new font is also a lot more aesthetically pleasing and more accurate to real life. vietnam is a terrible track to drive on (that's only my opinion though) however zandvoort is excellent, the whole circuit is basically one corner and there's something about that that i love. just needs a few performance patches and bug fixes then this game would be perfect in my eyes.

9/10 would sBin again

From a multiplayer perspective, its very similar to F1 2019, which was a good game.   Its a shame we are asked to pay full price each year for relatively small changes.  I think the same outcome could have been achieved with a DLC pack for the two extra tracks.

I would like multiplayer to evolve a little e.g. separate lobbies for drivers who use no driver assists, and more penalties for people who deliberately drive others off the circuit, and perhaps some more stats to summarise your online racing efforts

title: F1 2020
review: A big step up from F1 2019 with regards to features. My Team is an absolute dream come true for any avid motorsport manager player. And, with the opportunity to play throught the whole of the f2 2019 season in driver career, the progression feels much better than the 2019 game. For gamepad, and wheel-users alike, the handling has improved quite a bit. The cars, as they should, feel like an evolution, and no longer handle as much like "tanks". The podium pass is a fantastic addition too. Unlocking new levels feels quite rewarding, and seeing your car(s) in a shiny new livery is enough to keep me engaged. Overall, this game is perfect for the biggest f1 fans and even casuals.

title: F1 2020
review:
This game fills the spot on weeks when there are no F1 races in the real world, and is a great addition on real race weekends. I'm sure the game would be more fun if I had a racing wheel, but can't afford it on a teacher salary :) , but even with the Xbox controller it's an enjoyable race sim.
The new Make your own team addition is both long overdue, and well worth the purchase even when I already had the 2019 edition. The interviews are still pretty bland, but this isn't a RPG. What I'd love to see is a custom Livery creation option, as well as a custom team logo option. If you enjoyed any of the previous editions of F1, the 2020 version is a must have addition to your sim racing collection.

title: F1 2020
review: I usually only buy an F1 game every other year, but with the addition of My Team this year I had to buy this. While being pretty simplistic and not super in depth, it provides a level of customization that former F1 games lacked, and actually makes the career mode much more interesting. Choosing sponsors, liveries, second drivers, facility upgrades and more help this mode stay fresher for longer than in the past. Otherwise, it's the same deal as every other F1 games in terms of modes, but the handling model in this year's game is much improved and makes the cars feel weightier and grippier. The AI has also been retuned, and will make mistakes much more often than their robotic counterparts in former years. I caught Daniel Ricciardo out of Portier at Monaco when he had a kick of oversteer on the exit, which I had never seen the AI do before. It makes everything much more entertaining. While it's not perfect and there are some minor bugs, it's a very fun game that provides a good experience for casual and hardcore racing fans alike.

title: F1 2020
review:
Absolute blast. 

Adjustable Assists and AI allow you to race like a god and thunder through the back markers with a beer in one hand while texting with the other, just like in real life.

With no assists I can barely get out of the pit lane.

There are many F1 gamers out there that want a real 100% simulation, which I am sure you will get, but for the rest of us who can't back out of our drive way without committing a moving violation and leaving tire tracks on the carefully manicured lawn opposite, this game is a blast.

I enjoy bombing around the track the actual F1 is about to race on that weekend. Nice to know I'm not the only one that doesn't make it past the first turn.

title: F1 2020
review:
Hi fellow racers/gamers!
Codemasters has actually done it this time. A perfectly balanced single player experience with a phenomenal 'My Team' mode, that puts you in the seat of the CEO and No.1 driverof your own F1 team. The racing with the AI is for the first time reminiscent of Geoff Crammond and very engaging. All pitstops and rules work pretty flawlessly and everything looks completely stunning. The controls feel tight with FFB lacking a bit of the fidelity of a AMS or RF2, but it is the best Codies implementation to date hands down! In actuality it is now fun to drive. For the first time EVER did I wish at the end of a 100% race for more laps. More laps to push the car to the limit and gain that one extra position. (I have not tried multiplayer yet.) 

-My rating- 
Graphics: 9.5/10
Sound: 9/10
Singleplayer Gameplay: 10/10
Controls: 8/10

OVERALL: 9/10

title: F1 2020
review:
The latest F1 game by Codemasters, F1 2020

This game is great!! One of the best after 2018, with the handling being very good again, the car feels planted through every corner and i have so much fun :D handling feels similar to 2018 actually, except braking is much easier on this game.

I LOVE the My Team career mode, it's the most immersive a career mode can get, creating your own team and managing it whilst driving it through a season! This career is way more fun than the regular driver career which i can find boring sometimes.

I also believe the engine sounds are the most realistic they have ever been. The Ferrari and Renault sound the closest to real life in my opinion.

The AI have improved again as well, feels like you're racing a real person when you're racing with them, makes me less bored of GP mode races.

The overtake button is a good addition, it makes ERS management so much easier, I hated managing it in the other games, I couldn't drive as fast as I could because the ERS was too low and I had to save it...

I feel the automated highlights have also improved from 2019, they actually show overtakes made during the races.


Now with those great features of the game, let's get onto some cons.

There are less options for helmets... kinda disappointing tbh, I can't use the design I used in 2018 and 2019 because it isn't an option :(

Game crashes, not as much as 2019, but this is still a problem, even for OP computers.

Bugs including:
- not losing a single part of your wing after hitting a wall hard (has happened to me and some others)
- Desynced timing and lag (especially in spectator view, there are timing glitches)
- Drivers can sometimes be on the podium with no heads or no body (this has been fixed)


Now you might be wondering: why did I not mention the communicating with online services "bug"?
Well, I honestly don't think it's a bug, it is just because the game has freshly come out and a lot of people are playing online and it can't handle it. I barely get it at all either so it's clearly not the game... it's related to the connection of someone to the host. Communicating with [b] ONLINE SERVICES [/b]. It's connecting to the game servers, so it's clearly related to connection in multiplayer. It's like when the internet speed at your home drops because a lot of people are using it. So yeah, rant over on that.

Overall, F1 2020 is one of the best F1 games to be made, with great handling, great features, and a career that brings me back into enjoying what I used to play before starting league racing! :D
LOVE THIS GAME

review:
Best F1 game I've played, the new my team mode is a lot of fun and actually makes you want to keep playing as you see how your team slowly makes progress through the grid, you can see how some circuits adapt better to your car depending on what you expend your resources points, trying to get sponsor objectives, signing a better teammate, and seeing how some drivers retire and the f2 drivers make the step into F1 has been really fun so far. I'm not even a huge fan of racing games or simulators but F1 2020 have made me start wondering if I should get a wheel just to get those extra tenths.

Can't really talk about the multiplayer though, I haven't really played there just yet, that's how much I'm loving the new my team mode. :)

title: F1 2020
review:
Finally a playable F1 game! Codemasters finally nailed it. They focused on and got rid of every issue that made previous years unplayable in my opinion. ERS mode is fixed, simple overtake button now. AWESOME. Better yet, driving in the wet is actually doable now and the AI isnt ungodly in their pace. Fantastic!

Side note, one issue that always made me mad was that the practice qualifying test always seemed to have a very unrealistic target pace. Learned that the target pace for the test is based on a more evolved track than you get at the first two practice sessions. If you wait for fp3 or end of fp2, that pace becomes more realistic. Hope that helps someone else, as that was one of my gripes before i figured it out.

title: F1 2020
review:
Definetly not perfect, but this is the best experience on an F1 official game so far. The handling model has been improved since last year and the "my team" career mode is the most fun i've had with a career mode ever.

Although i still wish that:

1. My team career mode and online car customization was better.
We have several examples of good customization in racing games. Customizations that could be in the game are custom liveries where you can place and color geometric shapes to make your car look how you'd like it, choosing the chassis look, like different noses, spoilers, aero bits, wheels and wheel colors, number placement, custom sponsor placement. And most of all: a decent color picker, because the one in game sucks.

2. Pit animations weren't atrocities from the 1990s like they are today, the car looks like it is floating when it comes in.

title: F1 2020
review:
The controls and physics are so much better than 2019 but i have 4 issues why i wouldn't recommend it:

1. The AI suffer from the 2019 issue where at certain difficulty levels they seem to not see you and plow through you on the corners and have no damage but near enough put you out of the race. This was patched in 2019.

2. When the safety car deploys the AI seem to stop dead on the track, overtaking gets you a penalty and stopping gets you a DQ for an unsafe stop on track.

3. I returned today to find all my data gone, only the cloud data remained. Sod starting my team again! Thanks.

4. That sodding "Communicating to Online Services" notification is consistently on all the the time and is seriously off putting let alone annoying when you are trying to grab screenshots from replays. We don't really need to see it to be fair, give us an option to hide it.

title: F1 2020
review: Honestly, this is a big step backwards from F1 2019. The handling of the cars feels more like a 90's arcade game than like you're driving an actual F1 car. The game is full of bugs in typical Codemasters fassion. If you enjoy doing lots of unimportant things other than actually racing then you may enjoy the new My Team career mode. This game is certainly not worth what they want for it. Wait for it to go on sale to buy it.

title: F1 2020
review:
I enjoy this game very much, and have had a great time with it, only a few errs and ahs have happened and need to be fixed, the tyre allocation bug, the time trial crash and the most annoying the communicating with online servers. (27/07/20 These issues are largely fixed, just the servers being annoying every once in a while) 

I enjoy the game greatly but removal of a large amount of classic cars, livery's now locked behind a store which involves a "Podium Pass" are quite the negative for people trying and playing this game for the first time or returning to the series.

Edit: I have been playing for a few more weeks now, I am enjoying it greatly but there are still issues that crop up and things that still bother me.

The Podium pass still is a let down that its there. The removal of classic cars honestly hurts now, I wanted to drive some of those classics on Zandvoort, The Tracks from previous years that are no longer here is disappointing, the excuse of tracks taking a year to make each is getting ridiculous, If the track was in the previous iteration of the game i.e Germany in 2019 why not just carry it over as it was, saying that graphics would need to be updated is a lie when half the tracks look exactly like they did 4-5 games ago (Changing the Lighting engine is not a good enough excuse for "graphical" changes), keep the tracks no longer in the calender so we can continue to enjoy them in Time Trials, Single Race, Multiplayer, etc. 

I hope we get to see the tracks that are appearing in this years revised Championship, Nurburg, Portugal, Imola, Mugello would be amazing to see and drive.

title: F1 2020
review:
I am a big F-1 fan and bought the game for a number of years.
A lot of people are enjoying  F-1 2020 - I wish I were also.

But all I get are crashes ...

Bought the game after patch 1.05 came out

Crashed right out of the box! Right after intro movie - EGO dumper.
Running Nvidia 1080Ti.

Have tried everything to remedy (I found online - no help from Steam or Codemasters)

Many Nvidia Drivers 

Steam says I have played 1 hour - - but it is just watching the Intro Video and EGO dumper. 

 Too bad I really love F-1 .

If you are lucky and it works on your system - it is probably a good game.

If not - expect hours of frustration - - - with no solution
Judging by online  discussions, many people with good systems are having bad experiences.

I can't recommend spending money for this.

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 2020, a racing game like no other. From the visuals to the audio down to the gameplay this game is fantastic, compared to 2019 codemasters have shown they can consistently put out yearly releases of F1 games and make it worth the price every. single. year. Let's start with the visuals, F1 2020 has some gorgeous visuals compared to 2019, improved shadows, shaders, and textures are a key part of the beautiful new visuals in the game. The gameplay is super fun, with the new OVERTAKE mode on F1 cars you are able to play more competitive in straits and it makes the competition super fun! The controls appeal to players using a wheel and a controller, F1 2020 is very flexible with controls and anyone can play it!

The new mode (My Team) is very cool and a very awesome addition to the game! Though I do wish there was more customization in regards to livery making, all the liveries seem very bland and doesn't really come off as something an F1 team would put on their cars, and in general I'd love for more customization with things like player number fonts, sponsors, I was thinking to maybe have custom liveries in the steam workshop, that would be cool!

My team has been greatly improved from last year! With a lot of new features, it steps the game up and really feels legitimate, I play it all the time, personally my favorite mode in the game.

That about does it for my review, thanks for reading! Hope you grab the game, I can guarantee you'll have plenty of fun :)

title: F1 2020
review:
Updated Review
I love racing games and the Codemaster F1 series of games so far. I've been buying this series since F1 2011 for what my opinion is worth. There have been good and bad games from Codemasters but on the whole mostly good. This one did not work for me originally and I got a refund from Steam. I was convinced by a fellow F1 fan and player to purchase it again and with a lot of work we were able to fix my issues. The game is as fun as the previous years and offers a couple of new challenges. It feels a lot like F1 2019 but the My Team and ERS aspect are cool add-ons. Graphically it feels similar to last years so you may still want to hold off unless you have to have the new features. There are still some bugs to be worked out but at least Codemasters seem to be working on patching the issues. I will leave my original post below because I feel like they really should have tested it before releasing it especially for the cost.
*Warning The game still does not work for some people. Lots of DX12 and crashing issues* 

Original Post
I have I loaded the game and got the bug where the car and driver are missing with a blank screen, figured out hot to fix it. I started new team mode which I do think is a cool idea. I go through 3 practices, qualifying, and a 29 lap race, only for the game to crash to desktop. I open the game and it wants me to do the race all over again? No way! It did ask me to submit my crash (ego dumper) but I'm not you beta tester Codemasters. I'm just the excited F1 fan who paid $60 for a buggy game. Luckily Steam gave me a refund. I love F1 games but It doesn't look that much better than 2019 and a lot of the cut scenes look pretty much the same. Oh and the paycoin micro transaction thing is kinda lame for the cost. The game might run fine for you but a lot of people are having problems with fixes that sometimes work. I may reconsider it if they fix the issues or I'll wait for a sale.

title: F1 2020
review: It is definitely a good addition to the F1 game series with the addition of My Team career mode but lacks immersive customization to make the most out of creating your own F1 team. The game still lacks a true customization option that A LOT of racing games now feature such as MotoGP or Forza where you can create and edit layers giving you the ability to create whatever you want. Instead the game took a lazy and greedy shortcut by just adding a "season pass" system that basically means you're paying for cookie cutter skins and emotes that look plain bad and kill any immersion making you stick out like a sore thumb. However, you can download or make mods for the game that give you the ability to make your own liveries, helmets or uniforms but that is not supported by the game. That all being said there is still the My Driver career mode that has a few new additions to it making it just as good as it's ever been.

There was no way to know the game thought I hadn't until the second last lap.) Purchase at own risk. It has problems.

Edit: The game has had many bug fixes since this review, including the false DQ for tire rules. This game has my full recommendation.

title: F1 2020
review:
This one is a pretty comfortable recommend from me. Do you absolutely need it over last year? Not really. But if you're an F1 fan or just a racing game fan - this is (for me) as good as 2016.

The My Team game mode is pretty enjoyable. It's got some kinks to work out but if the devs stick with it - it will (in my opinion) become the big attraction for people to play the F1 series. If you enjoyed Motorsport Manager (or really any of those management sport games) you'll enjoy it. If not - it's just as easy to do regular career modes, or hop into Time Trial and try to climb the leaderboards. Lots of promise for My Team and really excited to see where it goes.

Graphics are, as usual, fantastic - replays are well done and photo mode is very Instagram-like. Sound is good but I could use some more visceral noises from the environment like rumble strips and the like. UI is getting better although having to manage stuff for my season in the loading screens between tracks is still clumsy. AI is mostly fine - although I spent a lot of time playing GRID recently so pretty much anything that didn't block all of my overtakes and/or ram me off the track feels realistic.

The cars feels great this year. Some of the best handling and responsiveness I've seen in a racing game in quite a while. I play with a mix of controller/steering wheel depending on how many ****s I give that day and both work great. Feedback to the driver is very tactile and, much like driving a real car on a track, will give you as much information about what your car is doing as your eyes and ears will. That is, unless you turn on the assists. I know you might feel like you need that crutch but *don't do it*. Maybe TC at Medium to help with standing starts but really that's all I would use. Let yourself make mistakes. If you max out assists, you lose the feeling for the edge of your car's performance because it's always smothered by the computer holding your hand. Embrace the suck.

My biggest gripe with F1 is going to seem a little odd to most people - the Classic F1 cars. As of right now, all classic F1 cars are ranked on the same leaderboards in Time Trial. So the laps I turn in a '88 McLaren are gauged against 2004 Ferraris. That's... really discouraging. I don't think it would be too hard to sort them by chassis but it's been like this for several games in a row now.

Moving forward, I'm really looking forward to what they do with My Team. And I'd like to see some changes to the classic stuff. There are a lot of players out there who would love to see that developed more. Personally, I would like to see any cars past 2004 removed (everyone knows the 2004 Ferrari is going to post the best times anyway) and replace those with cars stretching back further into the 80s and 70s (and maybe farther back?). But more than that I would love to see some of the old tracks. Old Hockenheim. Old Spielberg. There are some really wild courses out there that we will never see cars racing on again - except in video games. The devs have the power to make it happen. And it's not like we need a perfect 1-to-1 Old Spielberg that's scanned in using GPS and whatever technical wizardry they use - just watch some old footage and wing it, it'll be good enough and people will eat it up.

title: F1 2020
review:
[h1] F1¬Æ 2020 - Refined and Revamped [/h1]

This review won't include an incredible amount of depth about the game mechanics in general, because I have covered the other games in different reviews, and this is mostly aimed towards those that have played the previous games and are unsure of whether the $60 price tag is worth the upgrade. F1 2020 is the third of the series I've played, the other two being 2018 and 2019, and I'll immediately start off by saying that it is by far the best, and my favorite of the three. While the overall feel and content of the game is still very obviously a built-upon version of the older Codemasters F1 games, 2020 delivers so many QoL improvements and overall engine upgrades that the feel of the game alone makes it worth buying for fans of the series. 

Firstly, and most importantly, the biggest improvement from 2019 and prior is the feel of how the cars actually drive. I'm not an expert in car physics, but I can certainly say that the general feel and maneuverability of the cars this year is such a vast improvement from the other games; They just feel more responsive, and are more fun to drive. Tire degradation also feels much more "accurate" (if you want to use that word), and different tire strategies feel a lot more viable now. Setups seem to make more of a difference in driving styles, and braking in particular feels a lot more responsive, and doesn't have that same "floaty" feeling that the older games had. In general, you feel much more connected to the road. 

Another area I love is the reworked ERS system. You no longer have to spend every exit changing your ERS settings, as the deployment has been simplified to a much more realistic "overtake button", where the only ERS setting you actively have to use during a race is the singular button. This change is much more akin to the real cars, and makes managing ERS much more newcomer friendly, and in general just feels better to deal with than the previous 5-tier settings. By proxy, this change also puts much more emphasis on changing your fuel settings (which are still: lean, standard and rich), which still provides an area for resource management without being constantly overwhelmed by spending a ton of time in the MFD messing with settings during the race. 

The highlight of the game outside of the driving so far has definitely been the "My-Team" career mode. This pseudo-rpg career mode puts you in the seat of a team-owner/driver, as you build up your own Formula 1 team from scratch, and borrows a lot of the old career mode rpg element car upgrades, with added areas of facility upgrades, sponsor management, teammate scouting and livery/team color customizations. As a whole, it basically feels like a more fleshed-out version of the classic career mode, with far more content that will take much longer to grow old than the original "MyDriver" career, which is still here, with the added benefit of the option to participate in the 2019 "scenario" F2 season, a reduced F2 season, or even a full F2 season as a preamble to joining the paddock of F1. 


[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*] Huge improvement in handling and responsiveness from previous games
[*] Revamped ERS system that is more user-friendly and easier to use
[*] New tracks are a nice change of pace
[*] MyTeam career mode is the most fun and most in-depth single player mode to date
[/list]

[h1]Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*] It is a steep price tag for a game that is at its core, a slightly upgraded version of 2019
[*] Online is still a hit-or-miss experience
[*] The VIP paddock pass (while easy to acquire tokens) is still an obvious micro-transaction scam
[/list]

[h1] Overall Score: 9 [/h1]

If this is your first F1 game, this is 100% worth the cost. If you're upgrading from 2019, I would suggest waiting for a price drop if you are a casual player, but if you live and breathe Formula 1 like I do, the new car physics and the MyTeam mode alone are worth the price tag.

title: F1 2020
review:
There really is no greater feeling than ripping around a course in a F1 car. Or so I can imagine thanks to this game.

There is NO time to think about anything while your driving. Time on straights between lightning fast corners is at most around 3-5 seconds. Then it's BAM on the brakes down to around 80mph right hand turn into a long fast left hander leading into a straight that gets you up to 200 mph. Then SLAM on the brakes and go all the way down to about 50 mph for a sharp right-hander into a left-hand turn at about 100mph and then another right at 100mph into a short straight up to 180, then down to 80 for a right-hander and turn on overtake mode and switch fuel to MAX for the straight and then SLAM on the brakes turn fuel down to low (make sure you turned off overtake mode you goddamn idi)and BANG on the gas for a long ass straightturnonovertakemodeandsetfueltoMAXandthenFUCKtheworstchicaneinthegame(alldownforce)turnoffovertakemodeswitchfueltostandarddownto5thgeargasonturnonovertakemodeswitchfueltomax(youjustwent120throughthatchicBAMMMMMbrakefrom200mphdownto3rdgearturnoffovertakefuellowawkwardrightTURNin4thSLAMonbrakesdownto1stgearandgetreadyfortheworstrighthanderintothebackstraightfeatherthefuckingthrottleandSMASH INTO OVERTAKE MODE UP TO MAX FUEL and there's a lap of Australia. Now do this 36 times just for practice/quali while you figure out your cars setup and get points to invest in your R&D department.

Now it's race-day. The AI is absolutely stellar. Close battles the entire 50% length of the race. 37 laps white-knuckling the steering wheel trying to push the car as FAR as I possibly can without overdoing the engine/tires. Sick overtakes leading into turn 6 throughout the race. Coming from 18th at the start to 13th. Not even close to the points but man it felt good.

There really is nothing like it. This game is incredible. 10/10.

title: F1 2020
review:
Introduction
Little about me. I have about 405 combined hours in Codemasters F1 games. Some experience in iracing and assetto corsa and ac competizione. Equipment consists of a Fanatec wheel and pedals.


Handling
For reference most Codemasters F1 titles have had issues with low speed grip and this title is no different. Where Codemasters has improved in is downforce, aero balance, braking, suspension and tyres. Ill go bit more into detail below.

Downforce
Downforce has been increased massively 2019 had nerfed downforce bit too much when reacting to the realworld regulations and we ended up with really understeery and draggy cars. Downforce has been increased massively to account for this while the drag seems to be about same.

Aero balance
Aero had a weird balance during 2019 you often times would go into a highspeed corner with a good entry and mid corner/exit get some rotation on the rear causing you to have to correct or spin out even though you had more rear wing and usually understeered into the entry. This has been mostly fixed. You can carry alot more speed into highspeed in Silverstone for instance.

Braking
In 2019 it was really easy to cause the tyres to lockup the tyres had no inertia which conflated the understeering issue. The tyres now better simulate inertia and won't lock up as much but they might've gone bit too far. Now you usually only lock if you turn with about 60-100% brake force. Braking in a straight line you will start locking up at 1-2 gear with almost 100% braking which is bit nuts. Overall I prefer this over 2019 though.

Suspension
The suspension seems to be really forgiving on kerbs maybe a bit too as you can observe the tyre go up 30cm in a frame then go down without unsettling the car. The overall feel is more predictable though.

Tyres
Seems that the tyres load up better and have slightly more lateral grip you don't slide sideways as much in 2020 as in 2019. Apparently the tyres have been reworked massively but I don't really feel much difference, the preassure now changes dynamically though meaning cold tyres are less inflated and heating them up increases preassures. It would be good to add a tyre preassure screen on the mfd too.

Gameplay aspects
FINALLY A VIRTUAL MIRROR.
My team isn't a total flop, but the liveries are a bit uninspired.
Default setups aren't the same ones as in 2016 and have actually been changed to reflect the changes the game has undergone unlike every other F1 game so far.
Virtual currency, for a premium pass. I do not like this at all it is a worrying direction of more monetization for a 60‚Ç¨ game.
Performance is about the same as last year, still no VR support or real multiscreen support which is a bit dissapointing for a esports title.
Allows for dynamic resolution though which should give smoother framerate on low end machines.

Overall it's a massive improvement on 2019, but that's mostly because 2019 was a huge step backwards.

title: F1 2020
review: This game is currently BROKEN. I never review games but i will on this one. I had and played F1 2019 and it was fantastic. The AI in this game is certainly broken. I play with my nannies turned off and traction control on low. My AI skill level i have set to 60%. I not dont always get 1st in qualifying and thats ok, i like the challenge. BUT!!!!! when you get into the race its like a damn bumper car race. they dive into you like they are on a rail system and push you out of the way with force thats not possible with these cars. they always spin you out and clip off your front wing. i try to have as clean of a race as possible even if that means losing a position. but its absolutely unplayable. ive gotten rear ended and pushed into the wall, while the car that hit me drive off like i wasnt even there. hopefully there will a fix to this. i wish i could return this game. i will try. i know that the AI is a huge factor in this game. but take this problem out of it, the game is incredible. really well thought out. BUT FOR NOW, ITS SO BEYOND BROKEN AND PLAYABLE

title: F1 2020
review: After a friend recommended this game to me, I decided to give it a shot. I don't normally enjoy more realistic racing games. I never truly have. My only experience was playing NASCAR and the tracks are just so bland. Mastering the tracks in this game is a journey that never stops being interesting. Having to build a set up tailored for every track makes the game feel like the Escape from Tarkov of racing games. The driving mechanics feel smooth and fair. Honestly not sure I've played a better game! Also, the game has turned me on to the actual sport of F1. Never thought I'd be a racing fan! The politics and rivalries are a great draw and, as my friend puts it, it's fun to watch "a true test of man and machine being put to their limits."

title: F1 2020
review:
Probably the best F1 Codemasters game to date. The new My Team mode is great and adds a lot more to the standard career mode. Really hope they continue to expand this in the future, it's exactly what the game needed. 

There's also a new cosmetic item shop. Many items are unlocked through playing the game but other items require in-game currency to purchase. This currency can either be grinded out or bought with real money. Given that the items are purely cosmetic and most of the stuff you can get without spending money I'm inclined to give it a pass.

Otherwise the game gets high marks for graphics, sound, performance and car modelling. With very few bugs or issues. Definitely pick this one up if you like racing games.

title: F1 2020
review:
The game likes to crash, mostly after you win the Drivers Championship. It's as if the game doesn't know what to do once you win it so it says "F*ck it, you're done My Team"

The first time it happened , I let it be because I've encountered a few crashes before (It's more prevalent than you think) and just assumed since the game is new, I somewhat expected it to happen considering Codemasters history, so It needs a few patches/updates... so I replayed the race the next day, same result. My character does a few donuts to celebrate and the game crashed after. If I could simulate, I'd give it a shot but I'm passed that point.

As of now, I can't play the "My Team" portion because I'm pretty sure it'll do it again if I try a 3rd time and winning any points is me risking another crash, so I won't bother until I know it's fixed.

I'd wait on buying the game for now. It's really not a bad game but It needs some fixing. I'll change my review rating once It's fixed.

title: F1 2020
review:
Don't get me wrong, the singleplayer is perfectly fine, the cars feel way better compared to the last game, and I love the ERS simplification, but in its current state, I just can't recommend it at this price in this state. 

Singleplayer is fine, but it can get tedious, and multiplayer is where the replayability is. There's a bug that loops the "Communicating with Online Services" screen, and it can affect drivers mid-race. This alone basically makes multiplayer unplayable. Along with other small bugs, such as the person walking on water in the Australia cutscene, the timing bugs from last game at the start of MP races, and the STILL useless league system, it really just doesn't fly.

It's been two weeks since release, and people have had access to the game for far longer - this really isn't acceptable to have such serious bugs and to not have them be addressed at this point. If a patch does fix the communicating bug, then I'd probably recommend it, but in its current state.. only if you're interested in what singleplayer has to offer.

title: F1 2020
review:
As a whole package, F1 2020 is definitely on a new level compared to its predecessors. The cars handling and general driving feel have improved and the game feels a lot more smoother in general. Online multiplayer  also seems to have improved and is way less buggy than 2019. 

Some new game modes like "Create and manage your own team" and Splitscreen  have been sorely missed in the previous games and provide a new level of immersion. But this is where I feel some more work can be done. 

Upgrading your cars and facilities still seems a bit straight forward and trivial.  It would also be great to have the option of choosing a specific overall design philosophy for your car where one would  focus on either Aero, chassis, power or reliability. This would then perhaps unlock special upgrades or perks for that upgrade tree. Then the way in which one manages other aspects of the team could all influence how well your philosophy works. 

Customising liveries is still quite restrictive and those that are most appealing must either be unlocked by levelling up in the game, or by purchasing them through micro-transactions. I feel that codemasters could do better to give us full customising abilities, similar to NFS. Get rid of these pre-designed liveries or at least give us the option to design our own. And that's for helmets, drivers suits and gloves too.  I would also like to see some real sponsors in the sport as options for my team.

To end off,  I would 100% recommend F1 2020 to any motor sport enthusiast.

title: F1 2020
review:
As of right now, I would tell people to hold off on buying this game. There are some bugs that Codemasters clearly need to get worked out. When I first started out, I was really enjoying this game, because the "My Team" mode is a lot of fun. I made it through my first two races and then got to my third, which was "Hanoi." When i got to the second to last lap, my crew chief would come over the radio and tell me that I need to change to the compound (tires) that I haven't used. That seemed odd to me, because in that race you must use a soft or medium compound, as a mandatory requirement. Well, I started out that race with soft and my pit stop switched them to mediums, to finish out the remainder of the race. The first time, I ignored the crew chief, because he was simply wrong. Then, as soon as I hit the last lap...BOOM...DQ'd. So, I was like "okay, let's try this again." So, I restarted the race and when I got to the second to last lap the crew chief came on again, saying the same thing he said last race. I decided to just listen to him and when I came back around, I went into the pit and let them change the tires. Now, everything is fixed, right? NOPE...as soon as I left the pit...BOOM...DQ'd again, for not using the compound. 

I contacted Codemasters and they said something about it being a "mid-session save" issue. Well, that was about a week ago and I tried it again, today, with the same result. So, as I said (above), I don't recommend anyone buys this game, until Codemasters figure out the bugs and fix them. Apparently they need better game testers, because this seems like an issue that a blind monkey could have caught. 

I hope the fixes come soon, because when this game is running properly it's actually quite fun to play. Hope this review is helpful to the community and to Codemasters, because releasing games that aren't ready to be released is not a great way to do business.
