review:
Played a very small amount of this game, a few laps in Time Trial and 2 goes at Career having to reset it to change the difficulty. This game sucks! The ai can't corner so you either pass them with ease on a turn they just can't do or they push you out the way in the corners they can. DRS, ERS and the fuel mixing sucks, it just isn't fun having to micromanage and the unskippable talking in the interviews etc is really frustrating.

I asked for a refund but because I've played some of the game but Steam in their wisdom have denied it. I haven't even finished one race yet because I've had to reset to up the difficulty so many times which is why I'm over the 2 hours which isn't anywhere near long enough to test this game.

The game looks great and sounds great but it sucks, save your money, go buy an older F1 game before all the electronic BS was added. F this game, F Steam, F Codemasters and F you Vettel for slamming into me when you came out the pits! I had track position and would have just let you past after the corner but no, you spun me out and f ucked me over.

10/10, also amazing graphics.

title: F1 2020
review:
Best F1 game up to date.

Pros:
-still best career mode of all simulation racing games
-MyTeam career mode (POGCHAMP)
-very friendly to beginners 
-physics designed with the help of real F1 drivers
-cars feel a lot more predictable 
-great sound and graphics 
-improved AI that behave a lot more natural and make real mistakes from time to time
-cool new car designs and stuff to unlock via basically every race/challenge/time trial
-still a very high skill cap for those who really want to push the top times

cons:
-driving with certain assists can still give you the best times (debatable)
-very simplistic tire model, but its not bad at all as it is
-very limited track evolution (except weather transition)
-still limited car setup options, but you can now change tire pressure per tire instead of front/rear only
-nothing new for multiplayer except technical improvements and car skins
-very high curbs still dont kill you or your car like in real life (e.g. right inner curb at monza's second chicane)
-track limit penalties/warnings on "strict" setting are very unfair at some corners if you compare it to the real life racing line that the drivers are allowed to use even if they are behind the white line (e.g. Austria last corner). Sometimes the game will give you a warning, even if you lost time by running wide for example

Overall though a very solid game. 9/10

title: F1 2020
review:
An improvement from last year's game in all aspects. F2 is now longer, the handling is improved, there's new tracks, new cars, splitscreen mode (?), more customization, Will Buxton is there, you can have your OWN F1 TEAM. No contest here, as usual the newest F1 game is also the best F1 game so far.

The free to play mechanics on a paid game kind of miffed me a bit, but it's all optional and purely cosmetic content so it can safely be ignored. I wish there was a way to remove the XP windows from the summary, but oh well. This game is fun!!

title: F1 2020
review:
The game in itself, for one looks visually very good, with the requirements not being ridiculously high, the myteam mode is a positive and fun twist on career mode, although having hubert as a teammate is a little bit unsettling. I havent played the regular career mode yet, so im not sure what has changed exactly, now onto the online mode. 

In itself, its not too bad, the ranked and unranked is still a good idea, but theres a few bugs ive encountered a fair few times, for one when going into a lobby and going to spectate, when the race finished i am met with a black screen and have to Alt + F4 the game, which isnt too bad if it didnt happen every 5 or so rounds, this can also happen after a race, which if you're in ranked mode, decreases your safety rating and skill score, which is annoying as being a clean racer, (well i try to be), and getting left with the "D" safety rating, put in lobbies with lots of dirty drivers can get very frustrating and offputting from the game. Theres also the fact that you can get infinetely stuck on the grid, meaning you again, have to exit the game, which im guessing is server sided, that wouldnt be so bad if there also wasnt so many god damn crashes, i can be sitting on the grid, and then itll just crash, i can be traversing menus and itll crash, which, this combined with the other issues can make for an irritating experience, this being said if they do manage to sort these bugs etc, whivh have been in perviopus games as well, the game, both offline and online aspects of it would be very enjoyable.

oh and also split-screen which ive tried a few times, with myself, because yes, seems to work perfectly.

So TL;DR: good game with annoying bugs

title: F1 2020
review:
I honestly can't say I can recommend this based on my own sim racing experiences.  I love sim racing as a whole, but coming out of sim racing titles with VR support, playing this feels like a massive slog.  Not being able to judge distances and properly watch the road or mirrors has makes it hard to not make mistakes.  

I wanted so badly to enjoy My Team, but with the gameplay feeling like a massive chore to me and the AI happily killing you with zero consequences, I just can't bring myself to enjoy it.

So what about Multiplayer?  Sadly, it's kinda disappointing that nothing has really changed.  1-shot qualifying with track limit scrutineering that'll disqualify your lap if you so much as let a marble land on the lines.  I've never seen so many disqualified laps just from spectating alone.  In a lobby of 12 people, maybe 3-4 would make a lap.  I'll make a turn normally and my wheel will go onto the curb(as most racing lines would normally have you do) only to have the game go "NOPE INVALIDATED!"  I've ridden curbs on many tracks in other sims and they're never THAT strict!

I could go on for hours and hours about just how good this game is. The driving is fantastic, the graphics are good, the ai are phenominal (albiet make some questionable decisions at times) My Team is possibly the single best thing to be added to a racing game in a long time. Also, modding works again in the game, enjoy :)

title: F1 2020
review:
There appears to be bugs in game.
I can't watch replays properly as they seem to be automatically playing backward and stops. I need to force rewind to watch highlights.  Some key controls aren't completely free to map and are locked to certain preset controllers.  

There are some flaws in the way to select setups as well.  You have to use the keyboard F3 key to view the current custom set up to change it.  It would be much easier if this was able to be done with controller buttons and not required to have to be the F3 key.  

The game has crashed on me once so far. It also had issues rendering in the correct resolution with a usb-c to hdmi video adapter plugged into one of the extra slots.  Removing it made the game resolution match the main screen resolution.

title: F1 2020
review:
Probably one of the best handling models they've done so far. I use Logitech G29 and the car feels much better and the brakes are much more balanced than the other games which is amazing. 

The AI behaviour has improved massively as now they can crash and retire much more often.

There're still some car liveries that needs to be replaced such as black merc but i'm sure they'll do it in time as codies work really hard.

The amount of MyTeam & Multiplayer liveries is poor unlike the liveries we know in the previous games. Even tho there is a season pass it still feels poor sorry codies but i like them ngl.

The engine sounds and gear shift sounds are much better than the last years game.

The MSC Edition is definitely worth as you can play as The Legend himself and you can drive his previous cars. One thing that annoys me that the oldest historic car is '88 Mclaren. The fact that old Lotus, Ferrari cars are not available at this game kinda sucks.

The ERS system has been much complicated since the new era but what they've done at this game is a huge improvment as they added the overtake button which kinda feels more realistic as we hear on the team radio's.

The F2 journey to F1 Career path is quite fun but it the fact that i can go to a top tier team at my first year in F1 is kinda unrealistic to me and i'd be much more happy if i'd only have limited contracts and i wouldn't be the one who chooses them but to be the chosen person but it's still really fun.

And of course i must comment about the fact that you can literally get the legend, the myth Mahaveer Raghunathan and make him a 10 time world champion. 

The Casual and Standard gamemode's create a huge enjoyment for both the people who wants to challenge themselves and the people who just want to enjoy driving a F1 car. Fuel, steering etc. assists were really something some people needed a lot as they just wanted to enjoy the car or to people who drive with a keyboard which is really hard to operate the car.

I'd really want to play it much more often if i could have the time cuz i'm telling you the game is amazing but just like every amazing thing, it can be better and it can get improved a lot. A huge shoutout to Codies as they've done an amazing game for us to enjoy. 


In the end I'd rate this game

Scenario 7 Single Press Overtake Button out of Sore Loser

title: F1 2020
review:
I have no idea why I wasted money to buy the 2020 edition. Perhabs I was lured in by a prettier UI.
I can't really recommend this game. "Codemasters" have done it again. Driving with high-level AI is like driving a Ford KA amongst SUV's. When the AI hits you, you'll either lose a tire, your front wing or your temper. The AI will drive on as nothing happened.
Racing online is like a russian roulette. You take a chance in every lobby and pray that you won't eat the bullet, that's divebombing the first corner like a japanese pilot seeing a U.S. Navy ship outside of Pearl Harbor. 
I have no idea why i'm coming back for more in this game, maybe it's the adrenaline rush of avoiding the said pilot or a little hope of Codemasters honoring their name "CoDeMastER" and actually implement a fix. Anyway by judging of the 2019 game, I won't have my hopes up.

TL;DR
You like to get rammed? 10/10

review:
Love the game so far. "My Team" is a breath of fresh air into the franchise. 

On track feels great, UI is easy to navigate and intuitive. AI seems more aggressive, but not reckless. 

Wouldn't recommend upgrading from F1 2019 unless you really, really want to - as there are a lot of similarities. I did it because I really wanted to create my own team in career, and it's been worth it for me.

Haven't raced online and don't have plans to, so I can't speak on that.

Best iteration of the F1 series in recent years - and the default FFB is phenomenal (on a G29).

Also i think that the fact you can still go straight to a top team in the driver mode is unrealistic, rookie drivers hardly ever go straight to a top team and i think the game should show that.

title: F1 2020
review:
Alrighty, well, here we are again - another year, another Codemasters F1 game. 
There is good and bad here if you'll hear me out. 

I'll cut to the chase and say that on the whole its probably one of - if not the - best / most complete F1 games of the past decade and caters to a wide range of engagement; whether you're just interested in a more simple style of racing because you think F1 is cool, or if you like to go all in with no assists and full length weekends etc. 
The standard fare of modes remain, time trial, challenges, online - along with a returning collection of classic cars and F2 to make use of. 
The driving model has been tweaked since '19 and I'd say does offer a better experience across the board. 
The big selling point is obviously the "My Team" bit, and if you enjoyed any of the manager style games of F1's own mobile game it has cherry picked enough features to give an accessible but appropriately challenging management aspect alongside the standard career mode. 

Now, this is going to sound really picky but I think at this point (seeing as the main chunks of the game is only tweaked from year to year) we really should be holding Codemasters to a higher standard, and as good as the bulk of F1 2020 is, I can't help but feel they've got away with cutting some real noticeable corners here out of nothing more than laziness and because they alone hold the license for F1 games. 

F1 cars changed to a wider rear wing a few years ago now, and in the past three games, Codemasters still hasn't adjusted the pit crew motion capture to account for this (character clips his hands through the body to the narrower position). 
A lot of you might say this is incredibly niche and generally not noticed, but I'd say it shows a real lack of effort behind the flashy marketing of any new features. 
To the same effect, while the team and car customisation is good and wider in scope than previous games, its actually limited in key areas that feel they should be easy to implement and slightly sour the overall experience. 
Driver number style and colour on the car - seemingly tied to overall design preset, not individually customisable; steering wheel - not seemingly customisable (again, sure you can turn it off or you shouldn't be looking at it, but it is front and centre in the car if you play cockpit view and would be nice to select from 3-4 designs?). 

If you like F1, from novice to seasoned racer its probably worth playing - its the best upgrade in several years. 
However, as I say, I think we need to start holding the devs to a higher standard across all aspects of the game.

title: F1 2020
review:
For a returning player from F1 2019, the simplification of the ERS system from the complex modes to a simple overtake button is a welcome change in maximizing your potential on track. The addition of the MyTeam mode has been loads of fun in building up your own team to contend with the rest of the grid.

Alongside that the additional modifiers to difficulty and ease of access has made F1 2020 the most accessible game for new players, and at the same time the most welcomed for veterans of the Codemasters F1 games.

A definite recommendation from me!

title: F1 2020
review:
Codemasters still has not fixed the terrible multiplayer from previous games. You'd better hope that guy who takes ages to load actually loads in, because you will have to wait for every player and there is no way of leaving the lobby while this happens outside of closing the game all together. This is particularly annoying since multiplayer is the only real way to play this game unless you like doing time trials endlessly or driving around shitty AI in career mode who don't seem to understand they can overtake or defend on the first lap. I would give an opinion on the ranked but I still haven't been able to connect to a lobby to play any of it.

No real improvement from last year outside of the overtake button making the controller usable in a competitive manner and the my team mode which will undoubtedly get tedious as your car becomes overpowered against mindless ai drivers.

title: F1 2020
review:
As usual, Codemasters released a great F1 game with lots of stuff to do. Even though it feels like F1 2019, the game is more fun. Here are my positives and negatives:
+ Better car handling.
+ Cars sounds good.
+ MyTeam mode is immersive and fun.
+ More classic cars.
+ Podium pass is a fun addition.
- EGO3 engine it starting to show it's age.
- Some stuttering/freezes occurs during corners (not everyone is affected by this).
- Career mode press interviews are the same as last year.

Overall, I give it 9 pit stops out of 10!

title: F1 2020
review:
Would definitely recommend if you've ever been a fan of sim-racing or F1 titles in the past. The new My Team mode is a great new challenging take on the basic career. It starts you off at the very bottom and if you set the difficulty of the AI correct, it's a very fun and rewarding challenge to crawl to the top while managing your drivers, facilities, R&D (be careful though, the rules change and you have to adapt your parts after seasons end), and contracts. The pit pass had me wary at first, but with just 35 hours in I'm already almost done with it. I don't really care about cosmetics in this game as I play cockpit and you can really only make other folks tail lights look so cool to me. That being said, there are some really neat liveries you can only earn by completing challenges within the game, so that was nice to see. 
All in all, would highly recommend for the tense ranked multiplayer ranked lobbies (though lobbies and servers still have typical latency problems - it's a game played all around the world and you'll feel it from time to time) and the new take on My Team. Definitely progress for the franchise.

title: F1 2020
review:
Great F1 racing game!  I put about 80 hours into F1 2019 and rather enjoyed it, but 2020 has been a fantastic annual upgrade over the previous year.  Introduction of MyTeam, 2 new Tracks, and a new handling model.  MyTeam is fantastic, and is incredibly in-depth given the potential hardships they had to deal with this year.

Additionally, there are some great new casual modes and assists for new fans.  If you are a beginner in F1 and are worried about the game being too difficult - don't be!  There are tons of new assists to help you learn the game, and then you can slowly peel them back as you continue to improve.

title: F1 2020
review:
The Codemasters Official Formula One games have been getting better and better each year and I must say F1 2020 Is no exception to this and belongs right onto this list.

SYNOPSIS??? IDK WHAT DO THEY CALL THIS? A BY-LINE?:
F1 2020 Add a whole load of new features some re-created for the new MyTeam Career game mode that is so close to being perfect but as a new game mode into the series is absolutely fantastic and we'll mostly talk about it but first;

HANDLING:
From F1 2019 to F1 2020 The game's handling model feels so much better, F1 2019 had this weird thing where the cars would feel incredibly light and you would often spin far too much because not enough information was given to where you could correct yourself in time, in F1 2020 The cars have a more weighted feel and more information is given through in my case a Racing Wheel. At the time the only complaint I have is that the cars don't translate tyre information at all this was also seen in the last two games, F1 2019 & F1 2018.

FORMULA 2:
In F1 2019 I absolutely hated the F2 Feeder series for the career let alone the F2 Cars themselves and mwah in F1 2020 They are soooooooooooooo much better and so much more fun to drive as like stated before these cars actually have weight to them and are actually controllable I might even end up doing a full F2 Season whenever I start my Driver Career which probably wont happen because of the addition of MyTeam : / but still a wonderful upgrade since F1 2019.

THE NEW CIRCUITS:
Before we head towards my favourite addition to the game we should address the "Elephant" in the room, the addition of the two new circuits, Hanoi The Vietnamese Grand Prix and Zanvoort the Dutch/Netherlands/Verstappen Grand Prix.

HANOI:
Let's get Hanoi over with first shall we,Starting as the 3rd race in the calendar is a pretty big problem for those who didn't develop Aero upgrades in their MyTeam Career which we'll talk about in a bit.Hanoi overall, is a lazy piece of shit of a circuit with a mild enjoyment in the Esses during Sector 3 before you make those dreadful last two corners that you'll never make it around without nailing you front wing or the bloke ahead into the walls.I'm someone who thoroughly enjoys Monaco, Sochi and Kinda Baku (Castle is scary as fuck man) as street circuits but circuits in general to race on but Hanoi is designed in the laziest way possible with the idea it'll improve overtaking, yeah right.All you need to recreate Hanoi is You grab A reallllllllly long straight and two asymetrical-eliptically-chicane squashed roundabouts with a wiggly bit with fuck all runoff and call it a day, racing around the track very difficult and if you enjoy the circuit, I fucken congratulate you man but honestly not a welcomed addition to the Formula One Calendar.
ACTUALLY IT'S SO HORRIBLE IN FACT LATIFI WAS LAPPING FASTER THAN I WAS AND LAPPING AI RAN ME INTO THE WALLS BECAUSE THEY'RE SO FUCKING CLOSE TO THE TRACK YOU CAN DO ANYTHING TO SAVE YOURSELF AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH....

ZANDVOORT:
Zandvoort is a beautiful addition to the Formula One calendar and Game with it of course being resurfaced to suit those needs. When I first heard of it's announcement I was skeptical on how it'll perform as a racing circuit for Formula One but honestly it's such a fun free flowing circuit, now we havn't seen it live yet because of stupid virus but so far in game it's pure fun that even at a 50% race distance I wanted more of the circuit as it's completely possible to overtake and battle with other players and AI.The pitlane I will admit is sketchy but if you slam on the brakes and turn on Pit Limiter as the dividing wall comes up you'll make the speed limit with 5-10Kmh to spare... except that one time I flew into the diving wall, sorry to those who's lobby I was in lmao : /...Overall, A welcomed introduction into the Formula One Calendar.Just can we have Hockenheim Ring back pls and if Codies are willing to add Mugello

MYTEAM CAREER GAMEMODE:
Now for MyTeam, MyTeam is fucking fantastic for a new game mode, it's amazing and it pretty much makes sense to have in an F1 Title, a sport where everything is dictated by team growth, management, Research and Development and so much more, the MyTeam Career game mode translates this incredibly well and extends on the RnD Features that have been expanding upon since F1 2016 Where it was first introduced at it's minuscule scale.
The ability to manage everything from your RnD Departments all the way to your Team Mates which can include Lord Raghunathan Mahaveer, you get to pick your engine suppliers from Merc, Renault, Ferrari and Honda which adds to the realism of the MyTeam Career.
As a sidenote, I have not touched the Driver Career you but you do get the options of Skipping or Running a Full, Half, Quarter F2 Season before you start in F1.

MYTEAM DRIVER MARKET:
I will say this, the driver market has its flaws but pretty much works as you expect it, drivers exist in the market and you can hire them when your current driver's contract expires which is beautiful however and i'll state this later on there needs to be a larger driver pool because we only have access to F1, F2 and Lord Mahaveer Raghunathan i'd personally like to see Ex-F1 drivers and maybe even the fictional driver you see whenever you use AI in a Multiplayer/Classic Car Lobby.

VEHICLE VISUAL APPEARANCE:
Something that had never crossed my mind but the more I think about it the more it makes sense, a game like Formula One needs some way of customising your Formula One cars or at least have the ability to dynamically alter the appearance of the vehicle dependant of your RnD tree this is sort of one of those minor details that'd make the game far more immersive I suppose but for multiplayer purposes a full customisation kit would be outstanding, would also make it so all the cars didn't look like a HAAS or Ferrari...

SEASON LENGTH (BOTH MYTEAM AND DRIVER):
So at the moment we have access to Preset season where we can add and remove desired races however I and a few other find that to be too limiting and really the best way they could've made the season system is exactly how they have it for Multiplayer Leagues and Singleplayer Grand Prix events where you have complete control of the entire season up to 42 Races I believe, don't quote me on that... And with that being said there should be the ability to create a new list of tracks each season during your career so if you wanted to you can recreate this current real 2020 season with several double headers and what not and by the time you finish that season you jump back into the full 22 race calendar.

RECOMMENDATIONS/THINGS I'D LIKE TO SEE IN FUTURE UPDATES/GAMES:
The things I would either like to see in next years game or in a future update mostly relate to the MyTeam Career, or they all relate to the MyTeam Career.

Something for the Driver Market that would be neat is the ability to hire Ex-Formula One Drivers as we have seen as of recently that Alonso is returning to Renault next year and I would personally like the ability to hire someone like Jenson Button or even Mika Hakkinen.
It would be nice to also see those fictional AI Drivers seen in Multiplayer/Classic Car drivers show up in the Driver Market too.

Another thing would be the addition that each 2 or 3 seasons a new randomly generated team joins, maybe comes up from the F2 Feeder series or is just a completely new team, idk I just think that'd be neat.

Something to turn the MyTeam into maybe a more Hardcore experience is the ability for the player to manufacture their own power units and maybe eventually be able to sell them off to other teams.

As stated way above vehicle appearance weather purposeful or dynamic would be a really logical and quality of life addition to the game.

Overall, Would 100% Suggest and Recommend F1 2020 To anyone weather they have owned a previous F1 Title or not.

title: F1 2020
review:
[b]This game is just amazing, in ALMOST every way.[/b] They have improved the car handling system, they have made the Multiplayer less buggy, and they have added SO MANY amazing features that we didn't have in F1 2019. Some of my favorite new features are [b]the virtual rear mirror view, split screen mode, new emotes and celebrations[/b] and of course [b]the MyTeam Mode[/b], which I've become addicted to.

However, something I complained about in the previous game is sadly still here. The [b]"penalty system" in Multiplayer races[/b] (time penalties, illegal overtakes etc.) can often be so unfair to the point that it ruins someone's whole race.

But despite this ONE complaint, F1 2020 is still [b]the best racing game I've ever played.[/b]

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 2020 is a joy to play in terms of driving, on-track battles and challenge. You know it's not as hardcore as sims like AC and rF2 but hey, at the end of the day I've had AMAZING wheel to wheel battles against the AI. With that in mind, let's go.

The MY TEAM mode: It's the big new thing in the game. The upgrades and options are cool, you will probably get a kick out of it, but the customisation options are completely underwhelming. The sponsor placements, the liveries, the race suit options... no matter what you do, at the end of the day your team will look like a cheap knock-off from an unlicensed racing game. It really stands out amongst the field, but not in a positive way. I'm playing it to have some fun, but the regular Driver career (starting with the full F2 season) is much more engaging imo.

In terms of content, F1 2020 packs a lot, a LOT. the tracks are great, including the additions from this year's season that never came to be. Zandvoort in particular is a rollercoaster. The cars also look great, the classics are still there (although the models from the 70s and 80s were removed, sadly), and the game still offers weekly challenges, pre-made championships and two career modes. There's a lot to do.

Gameplay improvements are noticeable, but my main highlight is the sound. The game sounds amazing, and they added many more interesting little details on the soundscape. It definitely seems like the sound folks were the ones who worked the hardest in this year's iteration.

There are bugs, there are typos and the career mode could definitely do with a lot more. Codemasters really has to step up the game in several fronts, but having played the game like crazy since the pre-release, I think it shows I'm having fun.

Oh, the Podium Pass thing, don't bother. It's a set of weekly challenges and a XP system to unlock customisation goodies. You don't need to spend money on it, not at all, just go and enjoy some good racing/

title: F1 2020
review:
[b]Summary[/b]
What can I say, coming from previous iterations of F1 games this by far, is the most developed, detailed and rewarding edition thus far. If you love F1 the new My Team mode is a enthralling addition, fighting your way with the Williams during your first races to the mid-field battles (this is as far as I have made it so far) has to be the most compelling reason to buy as a fan of the sport.

It is a strong recommendation for racing game fans and F1 enthusiasts without question, just don't jump into it expecting iRacing levels of accuracy or Grid first to last races.

[b]The not so great[/b]
It isn't all perfect though, there are bugs (thankfully no crashing this year), do not disconnect your controller at any point with the game open or you controller settings will reset to the default, forcing you to enable another profile, then enable your custom one. Others are related to face LOD's not loading in right away on close ups, or blurring of background drivers going haywire/flashing or just not rendering correctly.

Balancing of upgrades can seem quite broken, I currently have quite a few engine upgrades for the ERS systems and you can quite often just breeze past much faster teams and then hold them behind as they cannot overtake even with DRS. 

The AI is very very racey and that is great but performance on some tracks can vary wildly depending on the difficulty - I have spent most of my time with it set to 90 -105 depending on the track and game mode and can outperform my teammate by about 0.2 and 1.2 seconds in qualifying sessions.

Graphics performance is a strange one, most tracks run excellently with 21 other AI cars, but some like Austria's T7-T8 run up the hill have massive dips, even on my 3900X 1080Ti rig. I do not play with dynamic resolution modes enabled however and this will resolve the issues for most.

review:
This game is an improvement in many aspects on the F1 2019 game, the new My Team career mode where you create your own team to join as the 11th Formula 1 team on the grid is a great addition and very enjoyable. Sadly its also where this negative review comes from. I would wholeheartedly recommend this game if not for the numerous game crashing bugs I encounter when in the menus between races. I don't know how this managed to slip through QA but whenever I try to open the financial history tab in the my team menu, the game crashes. This is 100% reproducible on my system. I also just encountered one in the R&D upgrade tree menu. when I try to select the power unit upgrade tree the game also crashes. In my last race I also saw Hamilton's helmet and gloves T posing in my rear-view mirror a few metres above his car.

TLDR: This game has many improvements on its predecessor but the game breaking bugs are preventing me recommending this game. Once these crashes have been fixed, I'll change my recommendation to a positive one.

title: F1 2020
review:
This one is mixed for me, as all of codemaster's F1 games have been. Just to get it out of the way, for reference, I'm currently ranked gold in multiplayer, (I don't really do TT except to make a setup) but rank top 1000 on all circuits when I get to them, 105% AI is about perfect for me, I use a T300RS GT with no assists, and have been playing since F1 2010 (unless you count F1 1998 on PS1)... But yeah this is a long one. 

[b]TL;DR it's a step in the right direction, but many things that make this game infuriating are still there.[/b]

[b]Things that were improved that I like:[/b]
[olist]
    [*] Handling seems fine, a bit more planted. Can't downshift into a super low gear to get absurd amounts of "extra rotation." Although I will miss hearing JD say that, and that was my driving style from 2014 all the way through 2019. I prefer it this way now though, seems much more realistic and down shifting for a split second is no longer a safety net when overshooting the corner.
    [*] Can utilize 100% brake pressure with no force feedback pedals. No longer are people who run ABS able to just run 100% brake pressure and out brake you every time.
    [*] MyTeam is a nice addition, I don't really see a reason to play Career mode anymore unless you want to start with a specific team.
    [*] Finally starting to implement better track limits. It's a bit inconsistent atm, but hopefully they fix this. I would like to see the track limits be extended the same way they are irl. For example, the track limit should be extended to the outside of the red/white curbs on tracks like Redbull Ring (Austria).
    [*] I like not having to constantly change ERS for every corner and exit. The push to pass is a good addition, but I really really wish you could change it from toggling to on while pressed. 
[/olist]

[b]Neutral things I have noticed:[/b]
[olist]
    [*] Much harder to lock the brakes with no ABS now. I don't know if this is more realistic, or just made to be easier. If it's the latter, then this is a negative in my book.
    [*] Can 't change gear in pit lane. I personally would like to leave the pit lane in 2nd gear.
    [*] You can still brake while straddling the outside curb (for example Spain T1, left wheels on the left side of the curb, right wheels on the track). Because it's consistent I guess it's OK and you just get used to it, but I personally don't like the idea of having braking zones where you can unrealistically widen the track because there's magically grip off the racing line.
[/olist]

[b]Things that absolutely drive me up the wall:[/b]
[olist]
    [*] Why is it possible to accidentally shift into neutral still? Why is neutral even in the game besides when you're sitting on the grid (you never need to use neutral yourself, ever).
    [*] Still sometimes get black screen when a multiplayer session is over and you are returning to lobby. You have to cntrl+alt+del and restart. Sometimes it happens after the podium, and before the game awards you XP, nullifying the entire race you just did.
    [*] There's still for some unknown reason a "pre-qualifying intro video" between the lobby starting and qualifying for multiplayer. Everyone readies up, then you wait for everyone to load, then this stupid intro video plays that everyone skips, then you have to wait for everyone to load again before going to qualifying. WHY IS THERE A STUPID VIDEO AT ALL!?
    [*] If you lose connection to a multiplayer race, but are still in game, the screen gets smoked (really dark) and in the middle of the screen the text "RECONNECTING TO GAME" (or something like that) pops up, BUT YOU STILL HAVE CONTROL OF THE CAR! So you just have to hope you can drive without being able to see until you reconnect. It's absolutely absurd.
    [*] You get so many warnings before an actual warning is counted toward the 3 you get before a penalty pertaining to track limits. I don't understand at all. It's like warnings for warnings? You can abuse track limits and never actually get a penalty in ranked multiplayer.
    [*] The Career/MyTeam qualifying pace practice program time is absolutely horrendously difficult. With 105% AI in my first race in Australia (so no upgrades) I was over 0.600 seconds off the qualifying program. But finished 6th in the actual race? Actual race pace and the qualifying practice program time do not correlate in the slightest. 
    [*] For the competitions or ranked play, you should be penalized more for using assists. ie, winning a ranked 5 lap race should not gain a driver using assists the same XP as someone who wins a ranked 5 lap race without assists. 
    [*] Flying lap still molests your tires way too much over driving out yourself. Bahrain, for example, will wear your qualifying tires to about 6% by the time you get control to start your lap. Do the out lap yourself and you can begin your lap with only 1-2% wear.
    [*] Need a way to communicate on PC. Most people mute mics. I need to be able to type messages to the lobby. You should still have the option to mute or language filter, but every "racing incident" leaves one or both parties confused on what exactly happened. Or if someone purposely is driving you into the wall to stop you from overtaking, I should be able to make it known in the lobby what happened so we can vote kick.
    [*] Online "safety rating" has been a cool idea, but it's completely broken. You can get pole, lead the entire race and win, and still lose safety rating. It makes so sense.
    [*] Edit/view car setup button doesn't need to be its own button. Why can't I bind it to a button like, pit/DRS? I obviously have no use for that button while sitting in the garage... Right now it's stuck bound to "L2" or button 11 which is on the base of my steering wheel.
[/olist]

Everything else is basically the same or not worth mentioning. I have a lot of negatives, but there are still more pros to this game than the negatives I listed. It's just not worth it to list out every positive that carried over from previous versions. As you can see, I still recommend this game, and I think it's extremely fun. I'm having a real kick out MyTeam.

title: F1 2020
review: No mouse support again just like every other entry in the Codemasters F1 Video Game franchise. No mouse navigation in menus nor a mouse steering option. I'm physically disabled and can't use a wheel and pedals or controller so i'm restricted to using a few keyboard keys and a mouse. Steering in F1 or any other racing game with a keyboard is awful and unlike other racing games, F1 2020 has zero mouse support so I can steer the car. Assetto Corsa/AC Competizione, Automobilista 2, Project Cars 2, I-racing and Race room all have fully integrated mouse steering and mouse navigation but not F1 2020 or any previous F1 game. I'm a massive F1 racing fan and have pleaded with Codemasters via email since F1 2015 to add mouse steering but they reply saying they have no intention of developing it. A free to play racing game called Race room has mouse steering but a racing game with a multi million pound budget does not. Embarrassing ! I have refunded the game, I will keep my ¬£44.99 thanks Codies !

review: this title still falls short of sim status. driving physics, though improved, are still weaker than the proper sims available. this game's excellence, however, lies within its status as a complete package. most aspects of a real f1 season are game-ified and included brilliantly - something codemasters has excelled at since 2017. now, with the introduction of the ability to run your own team, managing pr, development, funds and sponsors, this game gets even closer to a perfect recreation of f1 in real life. compound the game's spectacular off-track aspects with the marginal but noticeable improvements to the driving physics and ai, and i find it hard not to recommend this game to any F1 fan. not a sim - but still a great game.

review: Gentlemen, a short view back to the past. Thirty years ago, Niki Lauda told us ‚Äòtake a monkey, place him into the cockpit and he is able to drive the car.‚Äô Thirty years later, Sebastian told us ‚ÄòI had to start my car like a computer, it‚Äôs very complicated.‚Äô And Nico Rosberg said that during the race ‚Äì I don‚Äôt remember what race - he pressed the wrong button on the wheel. Question for you both: is Formula One driving today too complicated with twenty and more buttons on the wheel, are you too much under effort, under pressure? What are your wishes for the future concerning the technical programme during the race? Less buttons, more? Or less and more communication with your engineers?

title: F1 2020
review:
[h1]Codemasters does it again, and even better![/h1]
[h2]A new F1 fan's perspective on the game and why he thinks you should buy it[/h2]
[h3][i]By: StrawHat[/i][/h3]

[h2]Why I bought it[/h2]
F1 2019 had a great impact on my life, as I've stated on that game's review I wrote, and, in short, it not only deepened my newfound love for the sport, but it also made it possible for me to reconnect with my father on that special sports-loving kind of way. Again, Codemasters, thank you dearly. This drove me to purchase this game basically one day after it's launch.

[h2]Why (I think) you should buy it:[/h2]
When it comes to racing games, a lot of people prefer the more arcade-y style. Games like Need for Speed, RedOut, etc. Games with a lot of flamboyance and sometimes deep mechanics. F1, however, is a completely different beast... Or is it?

Sincerely, one of the things I love most about this series of games is that it gives you, the player, the tools to craft a unique experience suited for your playstyle. You can make it as arcade-like or as real-life-simulation as you want, and this is a feature I think a lot more games should implement. 

And then someone comes and says:
[i]But why F1? It sounds and seems so... boring, so risk-free. There's no traffic, The tracks themselves are contained, controlled spaces. There's no feeling of, y'know, "rush"[/i] 

I've heard something along those lines countless times, and it is a wrong affirmation. While yes, there is no traffic or illegal aspects to F1 racing, it is the most dangerous of all, in my eyes.

First of all, these games have no rubber-banding. The AI won't simply b*llsh*t you out of a win because the devs thought it would make the game more "thrilling". No, you have your car, your opponents have theirs, may the best horse with the best horseman win. No BS. Pure and simple racing.

Second: Not only there is a "rush", but the tension and the pressure can sometimes feel bizarrely intense. I didn't realise this until I was in the middle of the pack in Monaco trying to not hit anyone while at 300kph in a COMMON STREET. Sometimes it can feel as if there's no room for breath, because there isn't. Mistakes will be severely punished, yes, and there's even a replay feature that allows you to flashback to any point you want within that replay so you can re-do whatever screwed you voer. It's a great tool for learning the ins and outs of driving these machines, and OH BOY does it feel good.


[h2]F1 2020 vs F1 2019[/h2]
F1 2020 is a very impressive improvement on 2019's mechanics, visuals and so on and so forth. Regarding what is, well, the same as last year's iteration of this game, I felt it was all improved in one way or another.

What they added, though, is realy special. My team mode is a blast, and I have a feeling i'll play that most of the time. If you can't be bothered with management, though, carreer is still there, still as great as ever.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
So, yeah, you should buy it. Not only because it's a great game and Codemasters did a hell of a job yet again, but to experience the amazing feeling that is partakin in the Formula 1 sport. Trust me, it's great.

title: F1 2020
review:
In terms of rankings:
1.) Driving an actual F1 car
2.) F1 2020
3.) F1 2019

The ERS management is a tonne simpler now, you just have a big fat button labelled "OVERTAKE" to turn it up for extra power. It's actually good now too, adds like 20 mph to the top speed even on a low end car.

They update the drivers now based on their real world performances, you get an in-game message saying "Driver stats have been updated" and a button you can push to apply it to your current save (by default it only affects new saves).

It's got two new tracks, but the previous tracks remain largely unchanged aside from some changes to the suggested driving line. 

Additionally some of the 2019 kinks are ironed out, such as the weird pit lane entry if you had Pit Assist on, which is now significantly smoother. The AI is a bunch smarter, and will overtake you in some pretty clever ways. in 2019, the AI cars had set pace times, which would decay overtime based on tire wear (as opposed to having to actually drive, it was like they were scalextric cars stuck to the driving line). Now, they seem to have to drive under the same physics system you do, subject to lock ups and occasionally running wide when the conditions get a bit weird. In 2019, the Safety Car was basically a mythical creature - this time it actually shows up. You can make your own team now, with your own livery and second driver (it's usually some obscure GP3 or old F2 driver)

2020 has its own issues, the practice program times are absolutely absurd compared to the difficult and incredibly hard to hit early on. This does however seem to level off once you get going with upgrades to your car. Also, the cars aren't hugely in tune with their real life counterparts, and the starting grid is basically always Merc-Merc, Ferrari - Ferrari, Red Bull, Red Bull, etc.

Overall, its better than 2019 so if you liked that you'll love this.

title: F1 2020
review: Really loving the game so far, feels like an absolute step up from 2019. For me the car handles a tiny bit different than 2019, it's easier to handle at normal times and more difficult when tyres are off (compared to 2019 handling). The AI seems to be way more fierce and realistic, I had to defend P15 in Melbourne in My Team way harder than I ever had to defend that position on F1 games. Yes the microtransactions part is disappointing but then if we have to have it as a part of gaming now then I guess Codemasters has implemented it well; as someone who mostly plays only career mode now I have reasons to play time trial or grand prix with the Torpedo. Same with My Team, every action that we used to take in the earlier F1 career modes now has some sort of tangible outcomes and hence decisions and developments feel important. This is an easy 9/10 for me, if not more.

In my opinion, it is.

title: F1 2020
review:
A few months ago I criticised F1 2019 for lacking some quality of life features you'd usually expect out of an F1 Game. And whilst we didn't get livery changes or helmet sponsors (smaller features in themselves) I think none of us expected MyTeam be this game's headline feature. Before the announcement of MyTeam it might've been sensible to predict F1 2020 would be an addon to F1 2019 as DLC, since there was nothing really special about the 2020 season itself. However, we got surprised to by far the most fun and entertaining gamemode in any F1 game, and is perhaps up there with some other great racing games modes as well.

MyTeam gives you the opportunity to create your own, personal dream team in the world of Formula 1, becoming the 11th team on the grid. It is your job to manage finances, fund development, find a suitable teammate, manage time and activities, manage facilities and most importantly of all: drive the car itself. The initial livery selection is rather slim and disappointing, but hopefully the next generation of content will allow for more in-depth creation. With the 'podium pass' (more on that later) you can unlock more liveries which are more visually appealing to you. You're also tasked with making a team badge, selecting team branding colours and making your race suits. Money is mainly gained through sponsors which you put on the car and race suits. The way you spend your money is completely up to you: want a top-of-the-line teammate? Cash out on a top tier driver. Want your car to get to the top as soon as possible? Focus on building your facilities. The same R&D system we know is still in game, and the build speed, quality and quantity is all managed by the respective department for that part. There's a lot of complexity to MyTeam that I can't explain in a review, so if you get the game do look into it more.

The handling model on this game feels a lot better than F1 2019 as well. With the input of real F1 drivers thanks to the virtual Grand Prix series, we finally have a slight indication as to how a Formula 1 car may feel. You can generally go onto the accelerator earlier and have more confidence putting the foot down, and the same applies for breaking and putting the breaks on later. Wet weather driving has become a lot easier to acclimate to easily, rather than having to guess breaking points like in previous games. I wouldn't say overall the game is easier, since the challenge of driving an F1 car will never be easy, even in the virtual world. But the small tweaks that the game has had have really separated this game from the rest and makes it my personal favourite by far. I've sunk nearly 70 hours into the game and I do not regret the purchase at all.

A controversial addition to this years game was the Podium Pass, a season-based system where level up to gain access to more liveries, poses, emotes and more. You can also pay "PitCoin" to level up, this doesn't affect your XP but does allow you to unlock the cosmetics you want. As you may have expected, PitCoins are gained by paying real life money, at least for the people who didn't pre-order, instead those who pre-ordered get a 15000 PitCoin bonus at the start. The Podium Pass VIP package allows you to get more bonus content from levelling up, alongside VIP challenges - this costs 9000 Pitcoin. There are also standard and series challenges you can complete, and all challenges give you some sort amount of XP to gain more levels. However the saving grace for the Podium pass is the fact that if you grind enough, it is actually possible to get enough PitCoin by levelling up to pay for the next season. My take on paying real life money to get features in already paid game is its own story, but I do like the approach Codemasters took to implementing this.

Every game has its bugs, so if you're still on the fence about getting this game I'd recommend waiting a couple of weeks for most of the bugs to get ironed out. If you're making a decision to get it right now, I think it's worth a shot. Don't expect a flawless experience straight away, the game is still in its early days but we should see a performance patch and numerous bug fixes over the coming days. If it ain't your cup of tea, the steam refund system is always a thing - just don't play over 2 hours and your money is guaranteed to be back. 

Hope this review helps someone.

title: F1 2020
review:
Leaping to this game from its 2019 predecessor feels like 2 steps forward and 0 steps back. The regulated engine audio on this game no longer sounds like your average muffled kettle, but rather something aggressive for once, with different engine pitches and sounds at different RPM's.

A major issue right from the get-go for this game is the controller vs wheel debate that‚Äôs been sprung around since the release of this game. A YouTuber by the name of TRL Limitless has brought up this issue by summarising that the controller is more favoured on this game as it has ‚Äúin-built‚Äù traction control compared to the wheel where you get no sense of the traction through the pedals and instead through the reliability of the force feedback in your wheel, whereas compared to the controller you get a sense of traction through the trigger rumbles and can accurately pinpoint when to go full throttle and when not to.

The new "My Team" feature added into this year's game sounds amazing on paper, and it is, but you're quite limited as to what you can play around with regarding how your car looks. For starters, you're given the standard FIA issued 2020 Formula 1 car, meaning you can't really tinker around with different body parts such as the front nose or the rear wing, meaning you're somewhat stuck with a car that closely resembles the Alpha Tauri. In addition to that, there's not much choice regarding the livery / sponsorship deals you can customise your preset car with. All in all, your car colours will definitely resemble something out of a 2010 flash game, rather than the real cars you compete against. Credit to Codies though, they did as much as they could to give you as much free will as possible without breaking any sponsorship deals that would require being put on a "non-existing" car. Regardless of these flaws, the new career mode is amazing as it gives you a true sense of racing in your own team; and the fact that you have to work your way up with what you have sounds like a more achievable dream compared to getting a free seat to a Mercedes W11.

The graphics on this game look astonishing with better lighting, FXAA, and general details compared to the previous game. In addition, the photo mode now supports a feature to take "super resolution" pictures, 9 times the current resolution you run in game. For example, because I run the game in native 3840 x 2160, I can take high quality images with a resolution of 11520 x 6480, as shown in the following photos:
[url=https://puu.sh/G6ao7/500bae0cfb.jpg]Photo #1[/url]
[url=https://puu.sh/G6aws/3cc355666d.jpg]Photo #2[/url]
[url=https://puu.sh/G6ayJ/d8a3062dd3.jpg]Photo #3[/url] 
[url=https://puu.sh/G6arD/14190946d2.jpg]Photo #4[/url]
[url=http://puu.sh/G6b0I/c9b0060a66.png]Photo #5[/url]
Make sure to zoom in and see the details for yourself!

About the game in general though, the AI has been completely ramped up from the previous game; no longer is Hamilton the "OP AI" that leads the pack by a margin of 10+ seconds, but all of them got a general buff, relative to as they should be performing IRL this year (e.g. Albon, Leclerc, Bottas, etc.). As a general difficulty recommendation, 2019's 100% AI is somewhat comparable to 2020's 95% AI. I recommend using those figures to find out your suitable difficulty; the difficulty I commonly use is somewhere around 93-95 and I've barely skimmed over 10 hours on this game, as of writing the original review. 

However, a big issue for me is the exaggeration of dirty air on this game, something that the AI can visibly easily cope with. Following closely behind a car on a circuit with the combinations of "flat out" turns and turns that require the perfect braking + racing line such as Silverstone is damn near impossible as there's a high chance you lose traction as well as grip on the exits of turns due to said dirty air.

The new ERS mode is somewhat a debatable overhaul; there is no option to turn it off completely to recharge your batteries relatively quicker but it is a very useful feature as you can now maximise your engine power with one button rather than having to scroll through the MFD mid corner as you would in the last game. The new ERS mode also depletes incredibly quickly, so you have to carefully think about when to use it and if it's worth using it to defend an attacking opponent from behind or if you want to set the fastest lap in a race. However, because there is no way to turn it completely off, it is nearly impossible to save ERS on some tracks even when avoiding the overtake mode. For example, on Zandvoort, each lap saves a very minor amount of ERS compared to different tracks like Spielberg, where the combination of DRS and minor ERS can save a more significant amount of ERS.

After a couple of updates on this game, microtransactions have been added similar to how a ‚Äúbattle pass‚Äù would work on your modern shooters. Activate this so-called ‚Äúbattle pass‚Äù with your purchasable currency and you have access to working your XP up to unlock more varied and appealing liveries for your your ‚ÄúMy Team‚Äù / Multiplayer car, driver cosmetics, podium poses and whatnot. These cosmetics don‚Äôt affect the essence of the game in any way whatsoever but you be the judge of whether you appreciate the fact that a triple-A game has microtransactions regarding the customisation of an F1 car and its driver. 

Despite the "negativities" I've pointed out above, these "negativities" make the game lean more towards the simulation side of things rather than last year's sim-cade formula, as everything is in general much more challenging compared to last year.

To summarise, this is a fantastic game I can see spending the majority of my time on this year, cheers Codies.

p.s. black Mercedes asap pls ty

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 2020 provides an improvement over the previous games in the franchise, notably the accessibility options, 'My Team' mode, and the car handling to a lesser extent. With that being said, at time of writing it is still buggy, and is more or less crashing about as much as Grosjean does on a typical race weekend. 

The main question comes down to whether it is worth the ¬£45 price tag. My answer to that is that it depends. If you're a fan of F1 and have enjoyed previous games in the franchise, then I think this is a reasonably safe purchase for you. On the other hand, if you don't fit that criteria, then justifying the price tag is a bit more of a struggle, but, this game offers more accessibility options than ever to help inexperienced and newer players at the start of the game.

[u] Advantages: [/u]
- Greater accessibility options than ever before which is great for people like me, who could hardly be described as being particularly talented at driving virtual F1 cars 
- The 'My Team' mode adds an interesting dynamic to the game, and makes you feel more personally connected to the career mode. (The traditional career mode still exists if that's your thing)
- The cars just feel a bit better this year, I don't know quite how best to describe this, but I just feel a bit more 'connected' to the car
- The graphics are looking as good as ever, and the performance is good even on my somewhat mediocre PC
- The new tracks are well executed
- The ERS has been simplified to an overtake button, instead of constantly having to micro-manage it. To me this is a significant improvement, and makes the game more accessible

[u] Disadvantages: [/u]
- Still quite buggy, I'm sure most of these will be fixed in the 'Day 1' patch. In about 6 hours of game time my game has crashed about 6 times
- The 'pit coins' micro-transaction thing, really? I'm pretty sure this only gives you appearance stuff, but still this game is already ¬£45 as it is
- The AI still feels a bit ropey in places, especially in wheel-to-wheel battles, but it does feel like they've improved a bit since 2019. 

[u] Is it worth it? [/u]
More or less, especially if you're an F1 fan. If not, perhaps it's worth waiting for it to go on sale. It is definitely an improvement on last years game.

title: F1 2020
review:
Since F1 2019 physics was in my opinion pretty good, I had great expectations about F1 2020 but in the end I was really disappointed...the game physics is practically the same with added lateral grip (maybe a bit too much), but the worst part is car braking, where now the car has very little or nothing at all engine brake so you have only to rely on brake power...in this way you are forced to always put 100% brake pressure in the setup (in fact default setup already has 100%) and use your brake pedal with full range without modulating because wheel lockups is very uncommon (there practically seems to be some sort of hidden abs enabled)...that is why I asked for a refund because it's not what real drivers do when they brake.
Also Force Feedback (I have a Thrustmaster T300) is a bit worse (I don't think it's bad at all, but compared to F1 2019 you feel a bit less front tyres grip).
The only real improvement of F1 2020 is the fact that finally you have the overtake button instead of that crazy ERS management system and slipstrem effect has been reduced (it was overpowered), but that's enough to justify the buy and I also think that if I where to chose to buy F1 2019 or F1 2020 even for the same price I would  go for the first one.

title: F1 2020
review:
The series gets better and better every year!

This time they added a new mode called "My Team" where you built your own team and drive for it (like Bruce McLaren in the past did!). You can choose between all official engines (Mercedes, Ferrari, Honda and Renault) and choose a second driver out of all drivers in F1 and F2. I hope the modding community will be able to change the (a little bit boring) fake sponsors and replace them with real-world sponsors.

They also improved the handling of the car (downforce and throttle). Especially in wet weather I feel much more comfortable on the throttle (without any traction control turned on).

All in all I am very pleased with the new version. Codemasters again did everything right: Kept the good parts and adding a new stunning piece to the game (My Team).

title: F1 2020
review:
pros:
- Repolished career
- Obviously the new My Team
- Gamepad handles good, maybe a little too good
- Podium Pass which you can earn customization items in tier levels by playing the dang game, honestly a good feature
- Weekly Events (which i think probably needs to be more frequent race wise)
- Solid AI racecraft

cons
- AI sometimes are unrealistically too fast on straights (eg. F2 AI on 100%+)
- AI keeps getting bonked down on their second phase of race starts compared to player
- Classic car contents are sort of pointless aside from the few events, again
- Multiplayer experience and netcode are still a bit janky
- Random FPS drops here and there

overall a solid codies F1 game, 8/10

AI needs a lot of polishing in terms of balancing between all of the tracks, and the small stuff like the race starts. I hope they can fix these, including multiplayer and the graphical side of things, at least a month in.

title: F1 2020
review:
F1 2020 definitely seems like another good step in the right direction for the F1 games. Codemasters have made a good few improvements since 2019's game:

[b]Driving[/b]
When it comes to actually driving, I'd say the handling model has received improvements. The ERS system has been changed to more accurately reflect how the drivers control the battery in real life (based on real drivers' feedback). Importantly for non-multiplayer players, the AI seems much smarter this year, and much less likely to drive into you - provided you have a basic understanding of how to race them wheel-to-wheel.

[b]Features[/b]
The MyTeam mode gives Motorsport-Manager-like team control, while letting you still drive similar to career mode. The addition of a full Formula 2 season pre-F1 career is something I've long awaited personally. Multiplayer split-screen also returns - particularly with the addition of casual racing settings, it does seem like there's pretty much something for everyone.

It goes without saying that the game still has a handful or so of bugs, and it's still not quite an F1 sim experience, but I personally believe that this is the strongest F1 game there's been in a good few years.
---
[i]Note: I use a wheel to play, so I have no idea how well the game plays on a controller.[/i]

New Review:

So I have managed to stabilise F1 2020 on my PC so it's as rock solid as F12019.  I had to force it to Direct X 11 mode, and also make sure that my Logitech G29 steering wheel is connected *before* I turn my computer on, failure to do this will result in it ignoring my maximum wheel rotation settings.  I don't know what I'm missing from being in DirectX 11 mode exactly, but I'm getting high 90's FPS in UW4K so it's all good for me.

Anyway, I managed to have good session without any crashes, and although there are obvious bugs and annoyances that existed in the previous version, it's a great game and highly recommended.  Just be cautious that you might have crashes and wheel related issues that might need some tweaks.


Previous Review:

So far have played for around 100 minutes, it's crashed completely 4 times with an error reporting dialog appearing on the screen, shutdown my PC once. And totally messed with my steering wheel at one point that I couldn't even open the game until I powered it off and on again, even though the Logitech driver software was reporting everything working fine.

Disappointed, yes. Can't recommend until it works well enough to do time trial on a single circuit without it crashing.

title: F1 2020
review:
Where do I start.

It's a solid, even excellent, driving game.

However, without a day one patch it sure is buggy. I play on a very good pc rig and when it works, it shines, but if you use time-trial mode, as soon as you beat your closest rival it crashes. 

It desperately needs a patch or two, but I am confident that will come and it really will be an excellent game.

My biggest gripe is that Codies have stooped low enough to include micro-transactions.

DO NOT BUY THESE. DO NOT SUPPORT MICRO TRANSACTIONS IN ANY FORM. MICRO TRANSACTIONS ARE FOR MOBILE GAMES, AND EVEN THEN THEY ARE QUESTIONABLE.

For that reason alone, although I love the game I will not recommend it.

title: F1 2020
review:
I love this game even though one may argue that it is not sim like. In this review, I am just going to focus on wet weather driving as I feel that it is the biggest down fall of the previous iterations of the game. Please note I play with all assist off.

[h1]F1 2019:[/h1]
- The rear of the car is somehow just all over the place. I am able lose control of the rear occasionally in the dry and if I was driving in the wet, the car would just be sliding all over the place.

- Brakes are manageable in the dry but in the wet again they are atrocious. I really had to dial down the brake pressure by a ton just not to lockup. If I had a dry qualifying and a wet race, I just had to pray that I had the race pace due to having parc ferm√© enabled.

- Overall not really a good experience for driving in the wet.

[h1]F1 2020:[/h1]
- Really controllable car in the wet. However, if you push the car to its limits you still can lose traction. It is so much more fun to drive and the car is more predictable. This gives me more confidence in the car.

- Braking in the wet is so much more manageable and even in the dry too. It is less easy to lock up. Hence, I am able to run higher brake pressures for qualifying and the race as well.

- Overall racing in the wet boils down to how well you know the car and how much are you willing to risk in terms of acceleration. This leads to a more competitive racing.

To sum it all up, F1 2020 makes me look forward to wet weather racing. In the previous iterations of the game, I use to dread wet weather racing and it was really a struggle for me especially in career mode. [b]Lastly, not to forget that the game has so much more to offer this year![/b]

title: F1 2020
review:
[h1] F1 2020 brings the formula 1 season that the pandemic took away from us [/h1]

F1 2020 is the newest game in the annual F1 series by Codemasters. 2020 brings some much needed upgrades to 2019, and is a more polished experience. It comes with a new "create a team" option, and brings back local "split screen" racing, something that has been missing from f1 games since 2013!

I have not driven the game a lot, but the handling seems to have improved. I did not get any of the odd slides that plagued the previous F1 game, and I personally think the cars are a lot more fun to drive this year. F2 is back, but gone are Lukas Weber and Devon Butler, your two career mode rivals. I welcome this change, as Butler annoyingly used my racing number (71). Other than that, f1 2020 is practically a re-skinned 2019, with some quality of life changes, like a customizable HUD and a virtual rear view mirror.

However, there is one big change from 2019, which is the "Create Your Team" mode. In this mode, you are able to become the next Christian Horner, or Toto Wolff, and manage your own F1 Team. This means taking charge of car design, development, sponsor, facilities, teammates and more! Annoyingly, you can't just sit back and be the boss, as you still have to drive the car on the race weekends. Although the "create your team" career mode is a lot of fun and brings a new dimension to the f1 series, I still wish that I could hire two racing drivers, and just focus on managing my team. Maybe next year in F1 2021...

Once again, Codies have released a solid game. There have been a few changes to the irl cars very recently, but I imagine those will get patched in very soon, as codies have been pretty good about that on previous game launches.

title: F1 2020
review:
Massive improvement on the previous game, it's great to see that the developers are intent on actually innovating and improving the game year on year, unlike some annual sports games (cough, EA).

Improvements I noticed:
- Audio is much better, pretty much every sound in the game has been redone. I thought the cars sounded meh in previous games but in this one they sound much more like real life, I really like the Honda engine. Every impact from crashes to cars running over curbs or bumps now sounds much more crisp and real. 
- FPS problems completely fixed. Have not had a single issue with it.
- AI is noticeably better, 99% of the time. They are much more aggressive and capable when it comes to close racing, and they also behave in a much more "human" manner, you will sometimes see them making small mistakes, losing the rear on the exit of corners and the like. I have noticed a couple of issues, notably the AI does not know that you're not allowed to move across the track in the braking zone when defending, I lost 2 front wings because of that, and also they will drive straight into you when you are exiting the pit lane if they happen to be passing, so you may want to try using the manual pit limiter to avoid this. But overall the AI is great.
- Car handling feels a lot better. The slower cars with less downforce are harder to drive this time around once you turn off the assists but that's not a bad thing, it makes for a more challenging and fun experience overall. 
- ERS system is much better and seems to more accurately reflect real life, from what I've seen on the TV at least. It's much less of a chore to manage now.
- Entire new game mode where you create your own team, raise funds from sponsors, hire a second driver and develop your car over time. They managed to get the balance between accessibility and depth pretty much spot on with this, and I hope they build on it in future instalments. 
- Much more customisation options. Sadly there are microtransactions, but it's just for cosmetic stuff and there's a fair amount you can unlock just by playing. I'm gonna give them the benefit of the doubt on this one that it will stay that way and not go down the same path as other developers (cough, EA).

I've done six full race weekends and a bit of time trial and multiplayer, and honestly so far my only criticism is that the team performance in-game vs real life is quite off, in-game Ferrari is pretty much on par with Mercedes and has the best power unit in the game, which is definitely not the case in real life. Hopefully this will be patched soon. Oh and also the race engineer is dumb and kinda seems like he's watching a completely different race sometimes.

tldr if you like F1, buy it. This is arguably the best F1 game to date imo.

title: F1 2020
review:
I've been playing various racing and F1 games my whole life and this one is definitely the best.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
[u] Quick Pros [/u]
[b] Myteam adds a fun mode that will keep you occupied for hours on end [/b]
[b] Better AI that won't run you off as much (as long as you know how to race wheel to wheel) [/b]
[b] Free Podium Pass that adds cosmetic content for weeks to come [/b]
[b] Better car handling so you can be that much faster and more competitive [/b]

the car feels much better than 2019 did, where you'd seemingly lose the rear of the car for no reason now you can start to feel and drift that might start to occur and correct for it. (But all in all you just slide less.) 
My Team is definitely the reason to get the new instalment, i find myself wanting to do more of the background management than actually doing some of the GP's (especially Monaco.) team building is fun and watching your rise from a midfield car up to the top is something special to witness. Also with the new podium pass you won't be getting tired of your livery since they're adding new ones all the time, is it perfect? No, we'll get into in the bad but it does add more depth. Not to mention you can progress in the podium pass regardless of where or how you play.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
[u] Quick Cons [/u]
[b] Net code is still...iffy [/b]
[b] Bugs, lots of bugs (pre day 1 patch) [/b]
[b] Limited customisation for the artists out there [/b]
[b]  [/b]

For the not so good side of this game the first one that comes up is the bugs, now bare in mind the day one patch as of writing this has not been released, the bugs in this game aren't game breaking barring maybe one black screen after a GP that forced me to restart the race, and one particular bug that's just horrible, if you change strategy on the mfd, it'll set you to a 0 stop, you'll still complete your stops and change tires but sometimes it thinks you've only used one set and you're DQ'd. The ones that won't break your game you'll notice all over the place, npc's out of place during loading screens, character models missing limbs, most of them are visual but when they aren't and it affects your race it's infuriating, i'm sure that will have changed within days of this review being published. Online is fun as ever but don't expect all the cars not ghost via netcode issues or you to teleport in front or behind somebody, again this may be fixed soon but considering how f1 2019 was at times this seems like a small issue that we may just see from time to time. take away the rare teleport or ghost its a great online experience. Then there is the customisation and changing your badge and liveries, now let me get this straight there are a bunch of pre-made liveries, suits, gloves, helmets, whatever you can think of. You can also change the colour of said liveries, swapping a red for a white or whatever your heart desires. Now if you want anything past changing colours and choosing sponsors you're out of luck, no custom livery editor, or the small details you'd want to see from a team, yknow like their name on the car... it's small details like this i'm a sucker for and unfortunately you just don't see much of it. The badge you create is pasted everywhere and if you get one you like you'll be sure to be pleased when you see it but it would have been nice to get a more complicated badge like some of the other teams. WITH ALL THIS BEING SAID, I have heard of the ability to mod in different helmets and other designs, so this might fix all those issues but to miss out on an in house editor that was more than a colourway swap would have been nice in my opinion. 

[h1] The Conclusion [/h1]
There's a lot more to this game than what i'm willing to type in a steam review but all in all it's set to be the strongest formula one game we've had in mainstream gaming, there's something here for casual racers, and veterans who want to test themselves. Overall i'm pleased with the game but i welcome the patches that are without a doubt soon to follow, if you're fine wading through them prior to the fixes, well then join the club hah. If you are a F1 fan you'll enjoy this game, and if you're on the fence about if you really like f1 or not this game is the pinnacle of the series so far as far as dynamic career and team modes go. 

Hope this helped!

title: F1 2020
review:
First things first - this review is for/by people that aren't that great at prior versions of the game (or just don't have the reflexes to play at "real" difficulty). If you're wondering if the simulation is complex enough or if the tire wear perfectly matches the real season -- go find other reviews. :)

Ok... for those still with me who might be new to the franchise or just *terrible* at prior versions of the franchise (I'm the latter) -- here's why this is a good game to jump into F1 with.

Caveat 2: At this point, I'm 3 (and an Invitational) races into my first season using "My Team", so that's my perspective.

1) The "My Team" career option. If you enjoy the idea of managing sponsors, your other driver, your livery, engine partner, etc. without the full complexity of a Motosport Manager type thing and with still being able to drive (and hence steer the team destiny), this gives it to you. For those of us who would be told "git gud" on the discussion boards -- this also lets you drive with "Casual" mode (more on that next), so you have the option to focus more on the team or more on your driving (or both). Personally, I find it a lot of fun -- though sorry, Mick Schumacher -- you're going on the chopping block once your contract is up. Pass a car already, man!

2) The aforementioned "Casual" mode -- this is 100% why those of us who just aren't that good but want to have fun with F1 should buy this. Yes, if you want to become a world class driver you probably shouldn't start with it -- I get that. I know full well, I'm not going to be.... and for folks like me, this gives a nice set of assists that let you concentrate primarily on keeping the car on track and preferably at the apex as needed. It handles shifting (and to some extent braking/gas) for you. Braking, however - you'll likely quickly start to override as you get a feel for the car and the tracks. ERS is mostly managed, but again you can override. So -- like training wheels, I feel this lets more normal folks get going -- and then we can relax the assists once we get more of a feel for the game based on our own level. 
The only down side so far is that it prevents you from doing fuel mix management - which I mention because I can not pass the Practice Session fuel management regimens. Oh well.

3) Even in Casual, the AI doesn't take it completely easy on you. And there is a setting for it, so if you find the AI is being too gentle, you can start to ramp them up. I'm finding Mercedes still very competitive (especially on curvy tracks like Hanoi), so don't worry that you'll get a cakewalk -- there will still be drama and challenge even on the stock settings. Well, unless you're getting good - and then you can dial it up.

General comments on performance and whatnot -- it seems fine, graphics are nice enough. Sometimes I get some stutter (but I suspect that may of all things be Windows 10's wallpaper rotation - it causes hiccups on my system). Using an X-box wireless controller and it works well enough.

No comments on Multiplayer or Online stuff since that isn't my thing. I will note that there is LAN multiplayer as well as split-screen multiplayer (according to articles). Haven't tried those yet but expect to. So for a nice session with friends/family, looking forward to those options.

TL;DR: Fun for the newbie or the not-Leclerc crowd, adjustable challenge level but even stock casual has drama. Team management is a fun dynamic if you're into that (as I apparently am). Highly recommended.
